analyzed: parimitān eva ghaṭān karoti evam mahat api mahat ādi liṅgam parimitam bhedataḥ pradhāna kāryam ekā  buddhiḥ ekaḥ haṃkāraḥ pañca tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi pañca tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi
translated: In the same way, Mahat and the other effects are limited in number, as the effects of Pradhana.

original: pañcamahābhūtānītyevaṃ bhedānāṃ parimāṇādasti pradhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ yadvyaktaṃ parimitamutpādayati /
analyzed: pañca mahābhūtāni iti evam bhedānām parimāṇāt asti pradhānam kāraṇam yat vyaktam parimitam utpādayati
translated: There is one intellect, one ego, five subtle elements, eleven sense organs, five gross elements. Thus, because of the finiteness of the effects, there must be a cause, Pradhana, from which the limited manifest is produced.

original: yadi pradhānaṃ na syāttadā niḥparimāṇamidaṃ vyaktamapi na syāt parimāṇācca bhedānāmasti pradhānaṃ yasmādvyaktamutpannam /
analyzed: yadi pradhānam na syāt tadā niḥparimāṇam idam vyaktam api na syāt parimāṇāt ca bhedānām asti pradhānam yasmāt vyaktam utpannam
translated: If there were no Pradhana, then this manifest would also not be finite. And because of the finiteness of the effects, there must be a Pradhana from which the manifest is produced.

original: tathā samanvayādiha loke prasiddhirdṛṣṭā yathā vratadhāriṇaṃ baṭuṃ dṛṣṭvā samanvayati
analyzed: tathā samanvayāt iha loke prasiddhiḥ dṛṣṭā yathā vrata dhāriṇam baṭum dṛṣṭvā samanvayati
translated: Similarly, in this world, the well-known relation is seen, as when seeing a boy observing a vow, one infers

original: nūnamasya pitarau brāhmaṇāviti evamidaṃ triguṇaṃ mahadādiliṅgaṃ dṛṣṭvā sādhayāmo
analyzed: nūnam asya pitarau brāhmaṇau iti evam idam triguṇam mahat ādi liṅgam dṛṣṭvā sādhayāmaḥ
translated: Surely his parents are Brahmins. Having seen this threefold mark of Mahat etc., we conclude

original: 'sya yat kāraṇaṃ bhaviṣyatīti ataḥ samanvayādasti pradhānam /
analyzed: sya yat kāraṇam bhaviṣyati iti atas samanvayāt asti pradhānam
translated: This must be the cause of that. Therefore, from the doctrine of the relation of the whole and the parts, Prakriti exists.

original: tathā śaktitaḥ pravṛtteśca iha yo yasmin śaktaḥ sa tasminnevārthe pravarttate yathā kulālo ghaṭāsya karaṇe samartho ghaṭameva karoti na paṭaṃ
analyzed: tathā śaktitaḥ pravṛtteḥ ca iha yaḥ yasmin śaktaḥ sa tasmin eva arthe pravarttate yathā kulālaḥ ghaṭa asya karaṇe samarthaḥ ghaṭam eva karoti na paṭam
translated: Also, because of activity according to capacity. Here, one who is capable of something acts only for that purpose, just as a potter, being able to make a pot, makes only a pot, not a cloth

analyzed: ratham vā
translated: or a chariot.

analyzed: tathā asti pradhānam kāraṇam kutas kāraṇa kārya vibhāgāt
translated: Similarly, there is a cause called Prakriti. Why? Because of the division of cause and effect.

analyzed: karoti iti kāraṇam
translated: That which does is the cause.

analyzed: kriyate iti kāryam
translated: That which is done is the effect.

original: kāraṇasya kāryasya ca vibhāgo yathā ghaṭo dadhimadhūdakapayasāṃ dhāraṇe samartho na tathā taktāraṇaṃ mṛtpiṇḍaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇasya kāryasya ca vibhāgaḥ yathā ghaṭaḥ dadhi madhu udaka payasām dhāraṇe samarthaḥ na tathā taktāraṇam mṛd piṇḍaḥ
translated: The division of cause and effect is like this: A pot is capable of holding curd, honey, water, and milk, but a lump of clay is not so capable.

original: mṛtpiṇḍo vā ghaṭaṃ niṣpādayati na caivaṃ ghaṭo mṛtpiṇḍam /
analyzed: mṛd piṇḍaḥ vā ghaṭam niṣpādayati na ca evam ghaṭaḥ mṛd piṇḍam
translated: Or, a lump of clay produces a pot, but a pot does not produce a lump of clay.

analyzed: evam mahat ādi liṅgam dṛṣṭvā anumīyate
translated: Having seen the mark of Mahat etc., it is inferred in this way.

original: asti vibhaktaṃ tat kāraṇaṃ yasya vibhāga idaṃ vyaktamiti /
analyzed: asti vibhaktam tat kāraṇam yasya vibhāgaḥ idam vyaktam iti
translated: There is that divided cause of which this manifest is the division.

original: itaśca avibhāgādvaiśvarūpasya viśvaṃ jagat tasya rūpaṃ vyaktiḥ /
analyzed: itas ca avibhāgāt vaiśvarūpasya viśvam jagat tasya rūpam vyaktiḥ
translated: And for this reason also, because of the indivisibility of the universe, the universe is the form of that [Prakriti].

original: viśvarūpasya bhāvo vaiśvarūpaṃ tasyāvibhāgādasti pradhānaṃ yasmātrailokyasya pañcānāṃ
analyzed: viśva rūpasya bhāvaḥ vaiśvarūpam tasya avibhāgāt asti pradhānam yasmāt trailokyasya pañcānām
translated: The existence of the one having the form of the universe is the universe. Because of its indivisibility, there is Prakriti, from which there is no mutual division of the five

original: pṛthivyādīnāṃ mahābhūtānāṃ parasparaṃ vibhāgo nāsti mahābhūteṣvantarbhūtāstrayo lokā🔽iti pṛthivyāpastejovāyurākāśamiti etāni pañcamahābhūtāni pralayakāle sṛṣṭikrameṇaivāvibhāgaṃ
analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām mahābhūtānām parasparam vibhāgaḥ na asti mahābhūteṣu antarbhūtāḥ trayaḥ lokāḥ  iti pṛthivī āpaḥ tejaḥ vāyuḥ ākāśam iti etāni pañca mahābhūtāni pralaya kāle sṛṣṭi krameṇa eva a vibhāgam
translated: worlds, such as the earth and other great elements. The three worlds are contained within the great elements.

original: yānti tanmātreṣu pariṇāmiṣu tanmātrāṇyekādaśendriyāṇi cāhaṃkāre ahaṃkāro buddhau
analyzed: yānti tanmātreṣu pariṇāmiṣu tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi ca ahaṃkāre ahaṃkāraḥ buddhau
translated: Thus, earth, water, fire, air, and space - these five great elements, at the time of dissolution, become indivisible in the evolving elements, which are transformed into the five subtle elements. The five subtle elements and the eleven sense organs are in the ego. The ego is in the intellect.

original: buddhiḥ pradhāne evaṃ trayo lokāḥ pralayakāle prakṛtāvavibhāgaṃ gacchanti tasmādavibhāgāt
analyzed: buddhiḥ pradhāne evam trayaḥ lokāḥ pralaya kāle prakṛtau avibhāgam gacchanti tasmāt avibhāgāt
translated: The intellect is in Prakriti. Thus, at the time of dissolution, the three worlds merge into Prakriti. Therefore, because of the indivisibility,

analyzed: kṣīra dadhi vat vyakta avyaktayoḥ avyaktam kāraṇam
translated: like milk and curd, the unmanifest is the cause of the manifest and unmanifest.

analyzed: a taḥ ca
translated: And for this reason also.

analyzed: kāraṇam asti avyaktam pravartate triguṇataḥ samudayāt ca
translated: The unmanifest cause exists, it operates from the three qualities and from the assemblage.

analyzed: pariṇāmataḥ salila vat prati prati guṇa āśraya viśeṣāt
translated: From the transformation, like water, due to the specific substratum of each quality.

analyzed: avyaktam prakhyātam kāraṇam asti yasmāt mahat ādi liṅgam pravarttate
translated: There exists an unmanifest, well-known cause from which the effects beginning with Mahat evolve.

original: triguṇataḥ triguṇāt sattvarajastamoguṇā yasmiṃstattriguṇaṃ tatkimuktaṃ bhavati sattvarajastamasāṃ sāmyāvasthā pradhānam /
analyzed: triguṇataḥ triguṇāt sattva rajaḥ tamaḥ guṇāḥ yasmin tat triguṇam tat kim uktam bhavati sattva rajaḥ tamasām sāmya avasthā pradhānam
translated: From the three qualities: from the three qualities, i.e., from that in which the qualities of sattva, rajas and tamas exist. What is meant by this? The state of equilibrium of sattva, rajas and tamas is Pradhana.

original: tathā samudayāt yathā gaṃgāśrotāṃsi triṇī rudramūrddhani patitāni ekaṃ sroto janayati
analyzed: tathā samudayāt yathā gaṃgā śrotāṃsi triṇī rudra mūrddhani patitāni ekam srotaḥ janayati
translated: Similarly, from the combination, just as the three streams of the Ganges falling on Rudra's head produce one stream,

original: evaṃ triguṇamavyaktamekaṃ vyaktaṃ janayati tathā vā tantavaḥ samuditāḥ paṭaṃ janayanti
analyzed: evam triguṇam avyaktam ekam vyaktam janayati tathā vā tantavaḥ samuditāḥ paṭam janayanti
translated: in the same way, the unmanifest consisting of the three qualities produces one manifest effect. Similarly, the threads combined produce a cloth.

original: evamavyaktaṃ gunasamudayānmahadādi janayatīti triguṇataḥ samudayācca vyaktaṃ jagat pravarttate /
analyzed: evam avyaktam mahat ādi janayati iti triguṇataḥ samudayāt ca vyaktam jagat pravarttate
translated: Thus, the unmanifest produces Mahat etc. from the combination of the qualities. Thus, the manifest world evolves from the three qualities and from the combination.

analyzed: yasmāt ekasmāt pradhānāt vyaktam tasmāt eka rūpeṇa bhavitavyam
translated: Since the manifest arises from one Pradhana, it must be of one form.

original: naiṣa doṣaḥ pariṇāmataḥ salilavat pratipratiguṇāśrayaviśeṣādekasmāt pradhānāt trayo
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ pariṇāmataḥ salila vat prati prati guṇa āśraya viśeṣāt ekasmāt pradhānāt
translated: This is not a fault, because of transformation, like water. From one Pradhana, the three worlds arise, with specific differences in the substrata of the qualities.

original: lokāḥ samutpannāstulyabhāvā na bhavanti devāḥ sukhena yuktā manuṣyā duḥkhena tiryañco
analyzed: lokāḥ samutpannāḥ tulya bhāvāḥ na bhavanti devāḥ sukhena yuktāḥ manuṣyāḥ duḥkhena tiryañcaḥ
translated: The gods are endowed with happiness, humans with suffering, and animals with delusion.

original: mohena ekasmāt pradhānāt pravṛttaṃ vyaktaṃ pratipratiguṇāśrayaviśeṣāt pariṇamātaḥ salilavadbhavati /
analyzed: mohena ekasmāt pradhānāt pravṛttam vyaktam prati prati guṇa āśraya viśeṣāt salila vat bhavati
translated: The Manifest, which has originated from the one Primordial Nature, through delusion, becomes diverse due to the difference in the substratum of the qualities, like water.

original: pratipratīti vīpsā /🔽guṇānāmāśrayo guṇāśrayastadviśeṣastaṃ guṇāśrayaviśeṣaṃ pratinidhāya pratipratiguṇāśrayaviśeṣaṃ
analyzed: prati prati iti vīpsā  guṇānām āśrayaḥ guṇa āśrayaḥ tad viśeṣaḥ tam guṇa āśraya viśeṣam pratinidhāya prati prati guṇa āśraya viśeṣam
translated: The repetition is indicated by the word pratiprati.

original: pariṇāmāt pravarttate vyaktaṃ yathā ākāśādekarasaṃ salilaṃ patitaṃ nānārūpātsaṃśleṣādbhidyate
analyzed: pariṇāmāt pravarttate vyaktam yathā ākāśāt eka rasam salilam patitam nānā rūpāt saṃśleṣāt bhidyate
translated: The substratum of the qualities is the special substratum of the qualities. Taking that special substratum of the qualities as the basis, the Manifest proceeds through transformation, like water falling from the sky, which becomes divided due to contact with various forms.

original: tadrasāntarairevamekasmāt pradhānāt pravṛttāstrayo lokā naikasvabhāvā bhavanti deveṣu
analyzed: tad rasa antaraiḥ evam ekasmāt pradhānāt pravṛttāḥ trayaḥ lokāḥ na eka svabhāvāḥ bhavanti deveṣu
translated: In the same way, the three worlds, which have originated from the one Primordial Nature, do not have a single nature. Among the gods, Sattva is predominant,

original: sattvamutkaṭaṃ rajastamasī udāsīne tena te 'tyantasukhino manuṣyeṣu raja utkaṭaṃ🔽bhavati sattvatamasī udāsīne tena te 'tyantaduḥkhino tiryakṣu tama utkaṭaṃ bhavati
analyzed: sattvam utkaṭam rajaḥ tamasī udāsīne tena te tyanta sukhinaḥ manuṣyeṣu rajaḥ utkaṭam  bhavati sattva tamasī udāsīne tena te tyanta duḥkhinaḥ tiryakṣu tamaḥ utkaṭam bhavati
translated: and Rajas and Tamas are neutral. Therefore, they are extremely happy. Among humans, Rajas is predominant,🔽and Sattva and Tamas are neutral. Therefore, they are extremely miserable. Among animals, Tamas is predominant,

analyzed: sattva jasī udāsīne tena te tyanta mūḍhāḥ
translated: and Sattva and Rajas are neutral. Therefore, they are extremely deluded.

analyzed: evam āryā dvayena pradhānasya astitvam abhyupagamyate
translated: Thus, the existence of the Primordial Nature is accepted through these two arguments.

analyzed: itas ca uttaram puruṣa astitva pratipādana artham āha
translated: And after this, for the purpose of establishing the existence of the Spirit, he says:

analyzed: saṅghāta para artha tvāt triguṇa ādi viparyayāt adhiṣṭhānāt
translated: Because of the aggregate being for another's purpose, because of the difference from the three qualities etc., because of the superintendence,

analyzed: puruṣaḥ sti bhoktṛ bhāvāt kaivalya artha pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: The Spirit exists because of being the experiencer, and because of activity for the sake of isolation.

original: yaduktaṃ vyaktāvyaktavijñānānmokṣaḥ prāpyata iti tatra vyaktādanantaramavyaktaṃ pañcabhiḥ kāraṇairadhigatamavyaktavat puruṣo 'pi sūkṣmastasyādhunānumitāstitvaṃ
analyzed: yat uktam vyakta avyakta vijñānāt mokṣaḥ prāpyate iti tatra vyaktāt anantaram avyaktam pañcabhiḥ kāraṇaiḥ adhigatam avyakta vat puruṣaḥ u pi sūkṣmaḥ tasya adhunā anumita astitvam
translated: It has been said that liberation is attained from the knowledge of the Manifest and the Unmanifest. There, after the Manifest, the Unmanifest is understood through five reasons, like the Unmanifest. The existence of the Spirit is also inferred now.

analyzed: pratikriyate
translated: That is being refuted.

analyzed: asti puruṣaḥ kasmāt saṃghāta parārtha tvāt
translated: Why does the Spirit exist? Because of the aggregate being for another's purpose.

original: yo 'yaṃ mahadādi saṃghātaḥ sa puruṣārtha ityanumīyate acetanatvāt paryaṅgavat /
analyzed: yaḥ yam mahat ādi saṃghātaḥ sa puruṣa arthaḥ iti anumīyate acetana tvāt paryaṅga vat
translated: This aggregate beginning with Mahat is inferred to be for the Spirit's purpose, because it is insentient, like a bed.

original: yathā paryaṅka pratyekaṃ gātrotpalakapādavaṭatūlīprachādanapaṭopadhānasaṃghataḥ parārtho nahi svārthaḥ paryaṅkasya nahi kiñcidapi gātrotpalādyavayavānāṃ
analyzed: yathā paryaṅka pratyekam gātra utpalaka pāda vaṭa tūlī prachādana paṭa upadhāna saṃghataḥ para arthaḥ nahi sva arthaḥ paryaṅkasya nahi kiñcid api gātra utpala ādi avayavānām
translated: Just as a bed, an aggregate of each part - the foot, the lotus-shaped part, the legs, the cotton-filled cover, and the pillow - is for another's purpose, not for its own. Indeed, nothing at all is the purpose of the parts like the foot and lotus-shaped part of the bed.

analyzed: parasparam kṛtyam asti
translated: There is no mutual function among them.

original: ato 'vagamyate 'sti puruṣo yaḥ paryaṅke śete yasyārthaṃ paryaṅkastatparārthamidaṃ
analyzed: atas vagamyate sti puruṣaḥ yaḥ paryaṅke śete yasya artham paryaṅkaḥ tad para artham idam
translated: Therefore, it is understood that there is a person who lies on the couch, for whose sake the couch is, this body is

original: śarīraṃ pañcānāṃ mahābhūtānāṃ saṃghāto varttate 'sti puruṣo yasyedaṃ bhogyaśarīraṃ
analyzed: śarīram pañcānām mahābhūtānām saṃghātaḥ varttate sti puruṣaḥ yasya idam bhogya śarīram
translated: a composite of the five great elements, there is a person for whom this body is to be enjoyed,

analyzed: itas ca ātmā asti triguṇa ādi viparyayāt yat uktam pūrvasyām āryāyām trigunam aviveki viṣayaḥ ityādi
translated: And from this, the self exists, because it is the opposite of the three qualities and so on. It has been said in the previous chapter that the three qualities are the objects of the non-discriminating mind, and so on.

analyzed: tasmāt viparyayāt yena uktam tad viparītaḥ tathā pumān
translated: Therefore, the person is the opposite of that which has been said, in that way.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhānāt yathā iha laṃghana alpa vana dhāvana samarthaiḥ aśvaiḥ yuktaḥ rathaḥ sārathinā adhiṣṭhitaḥ pravarttate tathā ātma adhiṣṭhānāt śarīram iti
translated: Just as a chariot equipped with horses capable of leaping, running and galloping, when controlled by a charioteer, moves, in the same way, the body moves due to the control of the self.

original: tathā coktaṃ ṣaṣṭhitantre puruṣādhiṣṭhitaṃ pradhānaṃ pravarttate /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam ṣaṣṭhitantre puruṣa dhiṣṭhitam pradhānam pravarttate
translated: And thus it is said in the sixth chapter: The primordial nature operates when controlled by the self.

analyzed: atas sti ātmā a bhoktṛ tvāt
translated: Therefore, the self exists, because it is the enjoyer.

original: yathā madhurāmlalavaṇakaṭutiktakaṣāyaṣaḍrasopabṛṃhitsya saṃyktasyānnasya sādhyate evaṃ mahadādiliṅgasya bhoktṛtvābhāvādasti sa ātmā yasyedaṃ 🔽bhogyaṃ śarīramti /
analyzed: yathā saṃyktasya annasya sādhyate evam mahat ādi liṅgasya bhoktṛ tva abhāvāt asti saḥ ātmā yasya idam  bhogyam śarīram ti
translated: Just as a meal consisting of the six tastes - sweet, sour, salty, pungent, bitter, and astringent - is prepared, so is this body, which is to be enjoyed, of the effect of the great elements etc. Therefore, that Self exists for whom this body is to be enjoyed.

original: itaśca kaivalyārthama pravṛtteśca kevalasya bhāvaḥ kaivalyaṃ tannimitaṃ yā ca pravṛttistasyāḥ
analyzed: itas ca kaivalya artham a pravṛtteḥ ca kevalasya bhāvaḥ kaivalyam tad nimitam yā ca pravṛttiḥ tasyāḥ

analyzed: sva kaivalya artham pravṛtteḥ sakāśāt anumīyate asti ātmā iti yatas sarvaḥ vidvān avidvān ca
translated: inferred from the activity for one's own isolation. The Self exists, because all the learned and the unlearned

translated: desire the cessation of the continuum of worldly existence.

analyzed: evam ebhiḥ hetubhiḥ asti ātmā śarīrāt vyatiriktaḥ
translated: Thus, by these reasons, the Self exists, separate from the body.

translated: Now, is that one the overseer of all bodies, like a string made of jewels and pearls, or are there many selves as overseers of each body? To this it is said:

analyzed: janma maraṇa karaṇānām pratiniyamāt ayugapad pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: From the restriction of birth, death, and organs, and from the simultaneous activity,

analyzed: puruṣa bahu tvam siddham traiguṇya viparyayāt ca eva

analyzed: janma ca maraṇam ca karaṇāni ca janma maraṇa karaṇāni teṣām pratiniyamāt pratyeka niyamāt iti arthaḥ  yadi ekaḥ eva ātmā syāt tatas ekasya janmani sarve eva jāyeran ekasya maraṇe sarve pi
translated: And birth, death, and faculties. The meaning is that because of their specific restriction, their individual restriction.

analyzed: ekasya karaṇa vaikalye bādhirya andha mūka tva kuṇa tva khaṃja tva lakṣaṇe sarve pi
translated: If there were only one self, then when one is born, all would be born; when one dies, all would die; when one has a deficiency in faculties, characterized by deafness, blindness, muteness, lameness, and limping, all would be

analyzed: badhira andha kuṇi khaṃjāḥ syuḥ na ca evam bhavati tasmāt janma maraṇa karaṇānām pratiniyamāt
translated: deaf, blind, lame, and limping. But this is not so. Therefore, because of the specific restriction of birth, death, and faculties,

analyzed: itas ca ayugapad pravṛtteḥ ca yugapad eka kālam na yugapad ayugapat pravarttanam yasmāt ayugapad dharma ādiṣu
translated: And also because of the non-simultaneous activity. Simultaneous means at the same time, not simultaneous. Because the activity is seen to be non-simultaneous in regard to Dharma and other things,

analyzed: pravṛttiḥ dṛśyate eke dharme pravṛttāḥ anye dharme vairāgye nye jñāne nye pravṛttāḥ

translated: Therefore, because of the non-simultaneous activity, it is established that there are many.
