analyzed: dharmeṇa gamanam ūrdhvam gamanam adhastāt bhavati adharmeṇa
translated: By dharma, there is upward movement. Downward movement occurs by adharma.

analyzed: jñānena ca apavargaḥ viparyayāt iṣyate bandhaḥ
translated: And by knowledge, there is liberation. The opposite is said to be bondage.

original: dharmeṇa gamanamūrddhvaṃ dharmaṃ nimittaṃ kṛtvorddhvamupanayati ūrddhvamityaṣṭau sthānāni gṛhyante /
analyzed: dharmeṇa gamanam ūrddhvam dharmam nimittam kṛtvā ūrddhvam upanayati ūrddhvam iti aṣṭau sthānāni gṛhyante
translated: The upward movement is by virtue, making virtue the cause, it takes one upward. Upward refers to the eight realms.

analyzed: tat yathā
translated: Namely:

original: brāhmaṃ prājāpatyaṃ saumyamaindraṃ gāndharvaṃ rākṣasaṃ paiśācamiti tat sūkṣmaṃ śarīraṃ gacchati paśumṛgapakṣisarīsṛpasthāvarānteṣvadharmo nimittam
analyzed: brāhmam prājāpatyam saumyam aindram gāndharvam rākṣasam paiśācam iti tat sūkṣmam śarīram gacchati paśu mṛga pakṣi sarīsṛpa sthāvara anteṣu adharmaḥ nimittam
translated: Brahma, Prajapati, Soma, Indra, Gandharva, Rakshasa, and Paisacha. That subtle body goes to animals, deer, birds, reptiles, and immobile beings, where adharma is the cause.

original: kiṃca jñānena cāpavargaśca pañcaviṃśatitattvajñānaṃ tena nimittenāpavargo mokṣaḥ tataḥ sūkṣmaṃ śarīraṃ nivartate paramātmā ucyate /
analyzed: kiṃca jñānena ca apavargaḥ ca pañcaviṃśati tattva jñānam tena nimittena apavargaḥ mokṣaḥ tatas sūkṣmam śarīram nivartate paramātmā ucyate
translated: Moreover, by knowledge there is liberation. The knowledge of the twenty-five principles is the cause of liberation, by which liberation or emancipation is attained. Then that subtle body turns back. The Supreme Self is spoken of.🔽Bondage is said to be the opposite of that. Ignorance is the cause. And that is said to be the natural, the artificial, and the sacrificial bondage, as will be stated later.

original: viparyayādiṣyate bandhaḥ ajñānaṃ nimittaṃ sa caiṣa naimittikaḥ prākṛto vaikāriko dākṣiṇikaśca bandha iti vakṣyati purastāt yadidamuktam /
analyzed: viparyayāt iṣyate bandhaḥ ajñānam nimittam sa ca eṣa naimittikaḥ prākṛtaḥ vaikārikaḥ dākṣiṇikaḥ ca bandhaḥ iti vakṣyati purastāt yat idam uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: prākṛtena ca bandhena tathā vaikārikeṇa ca
translated: And by the natural bondage, and likewise by the artificial one,

analyzed: dakṣiṇābhiḥ tṛtīyena baddhaḥ na anyena mucyate
translated: Bound by the third with sacrifices, one is not liberated by any other.

analyzed: tathā anyat api nimittam
translated: Similarly, there is another cause.

analyzed: vairāgyāt prakṛti layaḥ saṃsāraḥ bhavati rājasāt rāgāt
translated: From detachment, there is dissolution into prakriti. Samsara occurs from rajas-born attachment.

analyzed: aiśvaryāt avighātaḥ viparyayāt tad viparyāsaḥ
translated: Non-obstruction from lordship, and the reverse of that, obstruction, from the opposite.

original: yathā kasyacidvairāgyamasti na tattvajñānaṃ tasmādajñānapūrvādvairāgyāt prakṛtilayo
analyzed: yathā kasyacid vairāgyam asti na tattva jñānam tasmāt ajñāna pūrvāt vairāgyāt
translated: Just as for someone there is detachment but not the knowledge of reality, therefore from detachment preceded by ignorance, there is dissolution into primordial matter.

original: mṛto 'ṣṭāsu prakṛtiṣu pradhānabuddhyahaṅkāratanmātreṣu līyate na mokṣaḥ tato bhūyo 'pi saṃsarati /
analyzed: prakṛtiṣu pradhāna buddhi ahaṅkāra tanmātreṣu līyate na mokṣaḥ tatas saṃsarati
translated: When one dies, one dissolves into the eight primordial constituents - pradhāna, intellect, ego, and the subtle elements. There is no liberation. From that, one transmigrates again.

original: tathā yo 'yaṃ rājaso rāgaḥ yajāmi dakṣiṇāṃ dadāmi yenāmuṣmiṃlloke 'tra yaddivyaṃ mānuṣaṃ sukhamanubhavāmyetasmādrājasādrāgāt saṃsāro bhavati
analyzed: tathā yaḥ yam rājasaḥ rāgaḥ yajāmi dakṣiṇām dadāmi yena amuṣmin loke yat divyam mānuṣam sukham anubhavāmi etasmāt rājasāt rāgāt saṃsāraḥ bhavati
translated: Similarly, this rajas-born attachment - I sacrifice, I give gifts, by which I will experience divine and human happiness in that world and here - from this rajas-born attachment, there is worldly existence.

original: tathā aiśvaryādavighātaḥ etadaiśvaryamaṣṭaguṇamaṇimādiyuktaṃ tasmādaiśvaryanimittādavighāto naimittiko bhavati brāhmādiṣu sthāneṣvaiśvaryaṃ
analyzed: tathā aiśvaryāt avighātaḥ etat aiśvaryam aṣṭaguṇa maṇima ādi yuktam tasmāt aiśvarya nimittāt avighātaḥ naimittikaḥ bhavati brāhma ādiṣu sthāneṣu aiśvaryam
translated: Similarly, non-obstruction from lordship - this lordship is endowed with the eight qualities such as aṇimā. From that lordship, there is non-obstruction, which is occasional. In the abodes of Brahmā and so on, lordship

analyzed: na vihanyate
translated: is not obstructed.

original: kiṃcānyadviparyayādviparyāsaḥ tasyāvighātastasya viparyāso vighāto bhavatyanaiśvaryāt sarvatra vihanyate /
analyzed: kiṃca anyat viparyayāt viparyāsaḥ tasya avighātaḥ tasya viparyāsaḥ vighātaḥ bhavati anaiśvaryāt sarvatra vihanyate
translated: And furthermore, the reverse of that, obstruction, from the opposite - that non-obstruction of that is the obstruction, the reverse, from the absence of lordship. Everywhere it is obstructed.

original: kiṃcānyadviparyādviparyāsaḥ syāvighātasya viparyāso vighāto bhavatyanaiśvaryāt sarvatra vihanyate // //
analyzed: kiṃca anyat viparyādviparyāsaḥ syā vighātasya viparyāsaḥ vighātaḥ bhavati anaiśvaryāt sarvatra vihanyate  /
translated: Moreover, there would be a reversal of the reversal, and the reversal of the obstruction would be the obstruction due to lack of mastery, being obstructed everywhere.

original: eṣa nimittaiḥ saha naimittikaḥ ṣoḍaśavidho vyākhyātaḥ /
analyzed: eṣa nimittaiḥ saha naimittikaḥ ṣoḍaśavidhaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: Thus, along with the signs, the conditioned has been explained in sixteen ways.

analyzed: sa kimātmakaḥ iti āha
translated: What is its nature? He says:

analyzed: eṣa pratyaya sargaḥ viparyaya aśakti tuṣṭi siddhi ākhyaḥ
translated: This is the creation of conditions, called reversal, incapacity, contentment, and accomplishment.

analyzed: guṇa vaiṣamya vimardāt tasya bhedāḥ tu pañcāśat
translated: But its divisions are fifty due to the agitation of the inequality of the qualities.

original: yathā eṣa ṣoḍaśavidho nimittanaimittabhedo vyākhyāta eṣa pratyayasarga ucyate /
analyzed: yathā eṣa ṣoḍaśavidhaḥ nimitta naimitta bhedaḥ vyākhyātaḥ eṣa pratyaya sargaḥ ucyate
translated: As this sixteenfold creation of signs and the conditioned has been explained, it is called the creation of conditions.

original: pratyayo buddhirityuktādhyavasāyo buddhirdharmo jñānamityādi sa ca pratyayasargaścaturdhā bhidyate viparyayāśaktituṣṭisiddhākhyabhedāt /
analyzed: pratyayaḥ buddhiḥ iti ukta adhyavasāyaḥ buddhiḥ dharmaḥ jñānam ityādi sa ca pratyaya sargaḥ caturdhā bhidyate viparyaya aśakti tuṣṭi siddha ākhya bhedāt
translated: Intellect is said to be the condition, determination is intellect, virtue is knowledge, etc. And that creation of conditions is divided into four kinds due to the differences called reversal, incapacity, contentment, and accomplishment.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ jñānam
translated: Among them, doubt is ignorance.

original: yathā kasyacit sthāṇudarśane sthāṇurayaṃ puruṣo veti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: yathā kasyacid sthāṇu darśane sthāṇuḥ ayam puruṣaḥ vā iti saṃśayaḥ
translated: For example, when someone sees a post, there is doubt as to whether it is a post or a man.

analyzed: aśaktiḥ yathā
translated: Incapacity is like this.

original: tameva sthāṇuṃ samyadgṛṣṭvā saṃśayaṃ chettuṃ na śaknotītyaśaktiḥ /
analyzed: tam eva sthāṇum samyak gṛṣṭvā saṃśayam chettum na śaknoti iti aśaktiḥ
translated: Not being able to cut off doubt by properly grasping that same post, it is incapacity.

analyzed: evam tṛtīyaḥ tuṣṭi ākhyaḥ yathā
translated: Similarly, the third is called contentment, like this.

original: tameva sthāṇuṃ jñātuṃ saṃśayituṃ vā necchati kimanenāsmākamityeṣā tuṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: tam eva sthāṇum jñātum saṃśayitum vā na icchati kim anena asmākam iti eṣā tuṣṭiḥ
translated: He does not wish to know or doubt that very post. This is the satisfaction that what is the use of this to us.

analyzed: caturthaḥ siddha ākhyaḥ yathā
translated: The fourth is called Siddhi, as follows.

original: ānanditendriyaḥ sthāṇumārūḍhāṃ valliṃ paśyati śakuniṃ vā tasya siddhirbhavati sthāṇurayamiti /
analyzed: ānandita indriyaḥ sthāṇum ārūḍhām vallim paśyati śakunim vā tasya siddhiḥ bhavati sthāṇuḥ ayam iti
translated: With delighted senses, he sees a creeper or a bird perched on a post. His success is in the form This is a post.

original: evamasya caturvidhasya pratyayasargasya guṇavaiṣamyavimardde tasya bhedāstu pañcāśat
analyzed: evam asya caturvidhasya pratyaya sargasya guṇa vaiṣamya vimardde tasya bhedāḥ tu pañcāśat
translated: Thus, of this fourfold creation of mental modifications, there are fifty varieties due to the conflict of the inequality of the qualities.

original: yo 'yaṃ sattvarajastamoguṇānāṃ vaiṣamyo vimarddaḥ tena tasya pratyayasargasya pañcāśadbhedā
analyzed: yaḥ yam sattva rajaḥ tamaḥ guṇānām vimarddaḥ tena tasya pratyaya sargasya pañcāśat bhedā
translated: Due to the conflict of the inequality of the qualities of sattva, rajas, and tamas, there are fifty varieties of that creation of mental modifications.

original: bhavanti tathā kvāpi sattvamutkaṭaṃ rajastamasī udāsīne kvāpi rajaḥ kvāpi tama iti // //
analyzed: bhavanti tathā kvāpi sattvam utkaṭam rajaḥ tamasī udāsīne kvāpi rajaḥ kvāpi tamaḥ iti
translated: Sometimes sattva is predominant, sometimes rajas, and sometimes tamas, when rajas and tamas are neutral.

analyzed: bhedāḥ kathyante  pañca viparyaya bhedāḥ bhavanti aśakteḥ ca karaṇa vaikalyāt
translated: The varieties are being described.🔽There are five varieties of error and twenty-eight due to incapacity and deficiency of organs.

analyzed: aṣṭāviṃśati bhedāḥ tuṣṭiḥ navadhā aṣṭadhā siddhiḥ
translated: Satisfaction is of nine kinds, and success is of eight kinds.

original: pañca viparyayabhedāste yathā tamo moho mahāmohastāmisro 'ndhatāmisra ityeṣāṃ bhedānāṃ nānātvaṃ vakṣyate 'nantarameveti /
analyzed: pañca viparyaya bhedāḥ te yathā tamaḥ mohaḥ mahāmohaḥ tāmisraḥ ndhatāmisraḥ iti eṣām bhedānām nānātvam vakṣyate nantaram eva iti
translated: The five kinds of error are: tamas, moha, mahat-moha, tāmisra, and andhatāmisra. The varieties of these will be mentioned immediately after.

original: aśaktestvaṣṭāviṃśatibhedā bhavanti karaṇavaikalyāt tānapi vakṣyāmastathā ca tuṣṭirnavadhā ūrddhvasrotasi rājasāni jñānāni /
analyzed: aśakteḥ tu aṣṭāviṃśati bhedāḥ bhavanti karaṇa vaikalyāt tān api vakṣyāmaḥ tathā ca tuṣṭiḥ navadhā ūrddhvasrotasi rājasāni jñānāni
translated: The varieties of aśakti (inability) are twenty-eight due to the deficiency of organs. We will also mention them. Thus, tuṣṭi (contentment) is ninefold in the ūrddhva-srotas (those who go upwards), and the jñānas (knowledges) are of the rajas quality.

analyzed: tathā aṣṭavidhā siddhiḥ sāttvikāni jñānāni tatra eva ūrddhva srotasi
translated: Similarly, siddhi (perfection) is of eight kinds, and the jñānas (knowledges) are of the sattva quality in the same ūrddhva-srotas (those who go upwards).

analyzed: etat krameṇa eva vakṣyante  /
translated: These will be mentioned in order.

analyzed: tatra viparyaya bhedāḥ ucyante
translated: There, the varieties of error are mentioned.

analyzed: bhedaḥ tamasaḥ ṣṭavidhaḥ mohasya ca daśavidhaḥ mahāmohaḥ
translated: The varieties of tamas are eight, and of moha (delusion) are ten, and of mahat-moha (great delusion) are eight.

analyzed: tāmisraḥ ṣṭādaśadhā tathā bhavati andhatāmisraḥ
translated: Tāmisra is of eighteen kinds, and so is andhatāmisra (complete darkness).

original: tamasastāvadaṣṭadhā bhedaḥ pralayo 'jñānādvibhajyate so 'ṣṭāsu prakṛtiṣu līyate pradhānabuddhyahaṃkārapañcatanmātrāṣṭāsu
analyzed: tamasaḥ tāvat aṣṭadhā bhedaḥ pralayaḥ jñānāt vibhajyate saḥ ṣṭāsu prakṛtiṣu līyate pradhāna buddhi ahaṃkāra pañca tanmātra aṣṭāsu
translated: First, the varieties of tamas are eight. Pralaya (dissolution) is divided from ignorance. It dissolves into the eight prakritis (primordial natures): pradhāna (primordial matter), buddhi (intellect), ahaṃkāra (ego), and the five tanmātras (subtle elements).

original: tatra līnamātmānaṃ manyate mukto 'hamiti tamo bheda eṣo 'ṣṭavidhasya mohasya bhedo
analyzed: tatra līnam ātmānam manyate muktaḥ ham iti tamaḥ bhedaḥ eṣaḥ ṣṭavidhasya mohasya bhedaḥ
translated: There, one thinks the self to be dissolved, thinking I am liberated. This is the variety of tamas. The varieties of moha (delusion) are eight.

analyzed: ṣṭavidhaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: it is of eight kinds.

original: yatrāṣṭaguṇamaṇimādyaiśvaryaṃ tatra saṃgādindrādayo devā na mokṣaṃ prāpnuvanti punaśca tat kṣaye saṃsarantyeṣo 'ṣṭavidho moha iti /
analyzed: yatra aṣṭaguṇa maṇima ādi aiśvaryam tatra saṃgāt indra ādayaḥ devāḥ na mokṣam prāpnuvanti punar ca tat kṣaye saṃsaranti eṣaḥ ṣṭavidhaḥ mohaḥ iti
translated: Where there is the eightfold lordship of the gem and so on, the gods such as Indra, due to attachment, do not attain liberation, and again, at the end of that, they transmigrate. This is the eightfold delusion.

original: daśavidho mahāmohaḥ śabdasparśarūparasagandhā devānāmete pañcaviṣayāḥ sukhalakṣaṇāḥ mānuṣāṇāmapyete eva śabdādayaḥ pañca viṣayā evameteṣu daśasu
analyzed: daśavidhaḥ mahāmohaḥ śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhāḥ devānām ete pañca viṣayāḥ sukha lakṣaṇāḥ mānuṣāṇām api ete eva śabda ādayaḥ pañca viṣayāḥ evam eteṣu daśasu
translated: The great delusion is of ten kinds: sound, touch, form, taste, and smell are the five objects of the gods, characterized by pleasure. For humans, these same five objects such as sound are also like this. Thus, in these ten,

analyzed: mahāmohaḥ iti
translated: there is great delusion.

original: tāmisro 'ṣṭadaśadhāṣṭāvidhamaiśvaryaṃ dṛṣṭānuśravikā viṣayā daśa eteṣāmaṣṭādaśānāṃ sampadamanunandanti vipadaṃ nānumodantyeṣo 'ṣṭādaśavidho
analyzed: ṣṭadaśadhā aṣṭāvidham aiśvaryam dṛṣṭa ānuśravikāḥ viṣayāḥ daśa eteṣām aṣṭādaśānām sampadam anunandanti vipadam na anumodanti eṣaḥ ṣṭādaśavidhaḥ
translated: The tamisra is of eighteen kinds: the eightfold lordship, the ten objects seen and heard. They rejoice in the prosperity of these eighteen, but do not approve of the misfortune. This is the eighteenfold

analyzed: vikalpaḥ tāmisraḥ
translated: discrimination, which is tamisra.

analyzed: tathā tāmisram aṣṭaguṇam aiśvaryam dṛṣṭa ānuśravikāḥ daśa viṣayāḥ tathā andhatāmisraḥ pi aṣṭādaśa bheda
translated: Similarly, the tamisra is of eight kinds, the ten objects seen and heard are like this. The andhatamisra is also of eighteen kinds,

original: eva kiṃtu viṣayasampattau sambhogakāle ya eva mriyate 'ṣṭaguṇaiśvaryādvā bhraśyate
analyzed: eva kiṃtu viṣaya sampattau sambhoga kāle yaḥ eva mriyate ṣṭaguṇa aiśvaryāt vā bhraśyate
translated: but when there is prosperity in the objects, at the time of enjoyment, he who dies or falls from the eightfold lordship,

analyzed: tatas tasya mahat duḥkham utpadyate saḥ ndhatāmisraḥ iti
translated: Then, great suffering arises for him, that is the darkness of darkness.

original: evaṃ viparyayabhedāstamaḥ prabhṛtayaḥ pañca pratyekaṃ bhidyamānā dviṣaṣṭibhedāḥ saṃvṛttā iti // //
analyzed: evam viparyaya bhedāḥ tamaḥ prabhṛtayaḥ pañca pratyekam bhidyamānāḥ dviṣaṣṭi bhedāḥ saṃvṛttāḥ iti
translated: Thus, the divisions of error, such as darkness, etc., when each is divided, become sixty-two divisions.

analyzed: aśakti bhedāḥ kathyante
translated: The divisions of incapacity are being described.

analyzed: ekādaśa indriya vadhāḥ saha buddhi vadhaiḥ aśaktiḥ uddiṣṭā
translated: The eleven types of injury to the faculties, along with the injuries to the intellect, are declared to be incapacity.

analyzed: saptadaśa vadhāḥ buddheḥ viparyayāt tuṣṭi siddhīnām
translated: The seventeen types of injury to the intellect are due to the reversal of satisfaction and accomplishment.

original: bhavantyaśakteśca karaṇavaikalyādaṣṭāviṃśatibhedā ityuddiṣṭaṃ tatraikādaśendriyavadhāḥ bādhiryamandhatāprasuptirupahvikāghrāṇapāko mūkatā kuṇitvaṃ
analyzed: bhavanti aśakteḥ ca karaṇa vaikalyāt aṣṭāviṃśati bhedāḥ iti uddiṣṭam tatra ekādaśa indriya vadhāḥ bādhiryam andha tā prasuptiḥ upahvikā ghrāṇa pākaḥ mūka tā kuṇi tvam
translated: And due to incapacity, there are twenty-eight types of injury caused by the deficiency of the means. This is declared. There, the eleven types of injury to the faculties are deafness, blindness, sleep, paralysis, loss of smell, loss of taste, dumbness, lameness,

original: khāṃjyaṃ klaibyamunmāda iti /🔽saha buddhivadhairaśaktiruddiṣṭā ye buddhivadhāstaiḥ sahāśakteraṣṭāviṃśatibhedā bhavanti
analyzed: khāṃjyam klaibyam unmādaḥ iti  saha buddhi vadhaiḥ aśaktiḥ uddiṣṭāḥ ye buddhi vadhāḥ taiḥ saha aśakteḥ aṣṭāviṃśati bhedāḥ bhavanti
translated: crippling, impotence, and insanity.🔽Along with the injuries to the intellect, incapacity is declared. Along with those injuries to the intellect, there are twenty-eight types of incapacity.🔽The seventeen types of injury to the intellect are due to the reversal of the divisions of satisfaction and accomplishment. The divisions of satisfaction

analyzed: saptadaśa vadhāḥ buddheḥ saptadaśa vadhāḥ te tuṣṭi bheda siddhi bheda vaiparītyena tuṣṭi bhedāḥ
translated: are

original: nava siddhibhedā aṣṭau ye te viparītaiḥ saha ekādaśa vidhā evamaṣṭāviṃśativikalpā
analyzed: nava siddhi bhedāḥ aṣṭau ye te viparītaiḥ saha ekādaśa vidhāḥ evam aṣṭāviṃśati vikalpā
translated: The nine divisions of success and the eight that are contrary to them, together they are eleven kinds. Thus there are twenty-eight alternatives.

analyzed: aśaktiḥ iti viparyayāt siddhi tuṣṭīnām eva bheda kramaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: The order of the divisions of success and satisfaction should be seen as the opposite of inability and so on.

analyzed: tatra tuṣṭiḥ navadhā kathyate
translated: There, satisfaction is said to be of nine kinds.

analyzed: ādhyātmikāḥ catasraḥ prakṛti upādāna kāla bhāgya ākhyāḥ
translated: The four internal ones are called nature, cause, time, and luck.

analyzed: bāhyāḥ viṣaya uparamāt pañca nava ca tuṣṭayaḥ bhihitāḥ
translated: The five external ones are from the cessation of objects. Thus nine kinds of satisfaction are mentioned.

original: ādhyātmikāścatasraḥ tuṣṭayo 'dhyātmani bhavā ādhyātmikā tāśca prakṛtyupādānakālabhāgyākhyāḥ /
analyzed: ādhyātmikāḥ catasraḥ tuṣṭayaḥ dhī ātmani bhavāḥ ādhyātmikā tāḥ ca prakṛti upādāna kāla bhāgya ākhyāḥ
translated: The four internal satisfactions are those that exist within the self. They are called nature, cause, time, and luck.

original: tatra prakṛtyākhyā yathā kaścit prakṛtiṃ vetti tasyāḥ saguṇanirguṇatvaṃ ca tena tattvaṃ tat kāryaṃ vijñāyaiva kevalaṃ tuṣṭastasya nāsti mokṣa
analyzed: tatra prakṛti ākhyā yathā kaścid prakṛtim vetti tasyāḥ sa guṇa nirguṇa tvam ca tena tattvam tat kāryam vijñāya eva kevalam tuṣṭaḥ tasya na asti mokṣa
translated: Among them, the one called nature is like someone who knows nature and its qualities and lack of qualities. By knowing that truth and its effect, he is satisfied only. He has no liberation.

analyzed: eṣā prakṛti ākhyā
translated: This is called nature.

original: upādānākhyā yathā kaścidavijñāyaiva tattvānyupādānagrahaṇaṃ karoti tridaṇḍakamaṇḍaluvividikābhyo mokṣa iti tasyāpi nāstyeṣā upādānākhyā /
analyzed: upādāna ākhyā yathā kaścid a vijñāya eva tattvāni upādāna grahaṇam karoti tridaṇḍa kamaṇḍalu vividikābhyaḥ mokṣaḥ iti tasya api na asti eṣā upādāna ākhyā
translated: The one called cause is like someone who, without knowing the truth, takes up the cause, thinking that liberation comes from the triple staff, water pot, and sacred thread. He also has no liberation. This is called cause.

original: tathā kālākhyā kālena mokṣo bhaviṣyatīti kiṃ tattvābhyāsenetyeṣā kālākhyā tuṣṭistasya nāsti mokṣa iti /
analyzed: tathā kāla ākhyā kālena mokṣaḥ bhaviṣyati iti kim tattva abhyāsena iti eṣā kāla ākhyā tuṣṭiḥ tasya na asti mokṣaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, there is no contentment called time for him who thinks liberation will come by time alone, or what is the use of practicing reality? He has no liberation.

original: tathā bhāgyākhyā bhāgyenaiva mokṣo bhaviṣyatīti bhāgyākhyā /
analyzed: tathā bhāgya ākhyā bhāgyena eva mokṣaḥ bhaviṣyati iti bhāgya ākhyā
translated: Similarly, there is no contentment called fortune for him who thinks liberation will come by fortune alone.

analyzed: caturddhā tuṣṭiḥ iti
translated: These are the four kinds of contentment.

analyzed: bāhya aviṣaya uparamāt ca pañca
translated: And there are five more due to the cessation of external objects.

analyzed: bāhyāḥ tuṣṭayaḥ pañca viṣaya uparamāt śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhebhyaḥ uparataḥ ūrjana rakṣaṇa kṣaya saṃga hiṃsā darśanāt
translated: The external contentments are five due to the cessation of objects - sound, touch, form, taste, and smell. One who is detached from acquiring, guarding, wasting, attachment, and injury sees this.

original: vṛddhinimittaṃ pāśupālyavāṇijyapratigrahasevāḥ kāryā etadarjanaṃ duḥkhamarjitānāṃ rakṣaṇe duḥkhamupabhogāt kṣīyata iti kṣayaduḥkham /
analyzed: vṛddhi nimittam pāśupālya vāṇijya pratigraha sevāḥ kāryāḥ etad arjanam duḥkham arjitānām rakṣaṇe duḥkham upabhogāt kṣīyate iti kṣaya duḥkham
translated: For the sake of increase, one should engage in animal husbandry, trade, service, and acceptance. This acquisition is suffering. The suffering of wasting is due to the loss of what has been acquired through enjoyment.

original: tathā viṣayopabhogasaṃge kṛte nāstīndriyāṇāmupaśama iti saṃgadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā viṣaya upabhoga saṃge kṛte na asti indriyāṇām upaśamaḥ iti saṃga doṣaḥ
translated: Similarly, when attachment to the enjoyment of objects is made, there is no cessation of the senses. This is the fault of attachment.

original: tathā na anupahatya bhūtānyupabhoga ityeṣa hiṃsādoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā na an upahatya bhūtāni upabhogaḥ iti eṣa hiṃsā doṣaḥ
translated: Similarly, there is no enjoyment of objects without harming beings. This is the fault of injury.

analyzed: evam arjjana ādi doṣa darśanāt pañca viṣaya uparamāt pañca tuṣṭayaḥ
translated: Thus, due to seeing the faults of acquisition and so on, there are five contentments due to the cessation of the five objects.

analyzed: evam ādhyātmika bāhya bhedāt nava tuṣṭayaḥ tāsām nāmāni śāstra antare proktāni
translated: Thus, there are nine types of satisfaction distinguished by internal and external differences. Their names are mentioned in other scriptures:

original: ambhaḥ salilamogho vṛṣṭiḥ sutamo pāraṃ sunetraṃ nārīkamanuttamāṃbhasikamiti /
analyzed: ambhaḥ salilam oghaḥ vṛṣṭiḥ sutamaḥ pāram sunetram nārīkam anuttamāṃbhasikam iti
translated: Water, water, rain, good rain, the other shore, good eye, woman, excellent water.

analyzed: āsām tuṣṭīnām viparīta aśakti bhedāt buddhi badhāḥ bhavanti
translated: But from the difference in the opposite powers of these satisfactions, there are obstacles to understanding.

analyzed: tat yathā salilam anoghaḥ ityādi vaiparītyāt buddhi vadhāḥ iti
translated: For example, from the opposite of not having water, not having water, not having rain, etc., there are obstacles to understanding.

analyzed: siddhiḥ ucyate
translated: Accomplishment is being described.

analyzed: ūhaḥ śabdaḥ dhyayanam duḥkha vighātāḥ trayam suhṛd prāptiḥ
translated: Invention, scripture, study, three kinds of relief of suffering, acquisition of a friend,

original: dānaṃ ca siddhayo 'ṣṭau siddheḥ pūrvo 'ṅkuśastrividhaḥ // //🔽ūho yathā kaścinnatyamūhate kimiha satyaṃ kiṃ paraṃ kiṃ naiśreyasaṃ kiṃ kṛtārthaḥ
analyzed: dānam ca siddhayaḥ ṣṭau siddheḥ pūrvaḥ ṅkuśaḥ trividhaḥ  ūhaḥ yathā kaścid natyam ūhate kim iha satyam kim param kim naiśreyasam kim kṛtārthaḥ
translated: and giving are the eight accomplishments. The three-fold goad is prior to accomplishment.

original: syāmiti cintayato jñānamutpadyate pradhānādanya eva puruṣa ityanyā buddhiranyo 'haṃkāro
analyzed: syām iti cintayataḥ jñānam utpadyate pradhānāt anyaḥ eva puruṣaḥ iti anyā buddhiḥ anyaḥ haṃkāraḥ
translated: Invention is like someone who thinks: What is true here? What is supreme? What is the highest good? What would make me successful? Knowledge arises in one who thinks thus: The self is different from primordial matter. Another understanding, another ego,

analyzed: tanmātrāṇi indriyāṇi pañca mahābhūtāni iti evam tattva jñānam utpadyate yena mokṣaḥ
translated: other subtle elements, senses, and five great elements - such knowledge of reality arises by which liberation

analyzed: bhavati eṣā ūhākhyā prathamā siddhiḥ
translated: occurs. This is the first accomplishment called invention.

original: tathā śabdajñānāt pradhānapuruṣabuddhyahaṃkāratanmātrendriyapañcamahābhūtaviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ bhavati tato mokṣa ityeṣā śabdākhyā siddhiḥ /
analyzed: tathā śabda jñānāt pradhāna puruṣa buddhi ahaṃkāra tanmātra indriya pañca mahābhūta viṣayam jñānam bhavati tatas mokṣaḥ iti eṣā śabda ākhyā siddhiḥ
translated: Similarly, from the knowledge of sound, there arises knowledge of the primordial matter, the soul, intellect, ego, subtle elements, senses, and five gross elements, and from that, liberation. This is the accomplishment known as sound.

original: adhyayanādvedādiśāstrādhyayanāt pañcaviṃśatitattvajñānaṃ prāpya mokṣaṃ yāti ityeṣā tṛtīyā siddhiḥ /
analyzed: adhyayanāt veda ādi śāstra adhyayanāt pañcaviṃśati tattva jñānam prāpya mokṣam yāti iti eṣā tṛtīyā siddhiḥ
translated: By study, by studying the scriptures such as the Vedas, one attains the knowledge of the twenty-five principles and goes to liberation. This is the third accomplishment.

original: duḥkhavighātatrayamādhyātmikādhibhautikādhidaivikaduḥkhatrayavighātāya guruṃ samupagamya tata upadeśānmokṣaṃ yātyeṣā caturthī siddhiḥ /
analyzed: duḥkha vighāta trayam ādhyātmika ādhibhautika ādhidaivika duḥkha traya vighātāya gurum samupagamya tatas upadeśāt mokṣam yāti eṣā caturthī siddhiḥ
translated: For the destruction of the three kinds of suffering - physical, elemental, and divine - one approaches a teacher, and from his instruction, one attains liberation. This is the fourth accomplishment.

original: eṣaiva duḥkhatrayabhedāt tridhā kalpanīyā iti ṣaṭ siddhayaḥ /
analyzed: eṣā eva duḥkha traya bhedāt tridhā kalpanīyā iti ṣaḍ siddhayaḥ
translated: This itself should be conceived as threefold due to the division of the three kinds of suffering, thus making six accomplishments.

original: tathā suhṛtprāptiryathā kaścit suhṛt jñānamadhigamya mokṣaṃ gacchati eṣā saptamī siddhiḥ /
analyzed: tathā suhṛd prāptiḥ yathā kaścid suhṛd jñānam adhigamya mokṣam gacchati eṣā saptamī siddhiḥ
translated: Similarly, the attainment of a friend is that someone, having acquired knowledge, goes to liberation. This is the seventh accomplishment.

original: dānaṃ yathā kaścidbhagavatāṃ pratyāśrayauṣadhitridaṇḍakuṇḍikādīnāṃ grāsācchādanādīnāṃ ca dānenopakṛtya tebhyo jñānamavāpya mokṣaṃ yātyeṣāṣṭamī 🔽siddhiḥ /
analyzed: dānam yathā kaścid bhagavatām pratyāśraya oṣadhi tridaṇḍa kuṇḍikā ādīnām grāsa ācchādana ādīnām ca dānena upakṛtya tebhyaḥ jñānam avāpya mokṣam yāti eṣā aṣṭamī  /🔽siddhiḥ
translated: Giving is that someone, by rendering service to the blessed ones through the offering of shelter, medicine, the three staffs, water pot, and so on, and food, clothing, and so on, obtains knowledge from them and goes to liberation. This is the eighth accomplishment.

original: āsāmaṣṭānāṃ siddhīnāṃ śāstrāntare saṃjñāḥ kṛtāstāraṃ sutāraṃ tāratāraṃ pramodaṃ pramuditaṃ pramodamānaṃ ramyakaṃ sadāpramuditamiti /
analyzed: āsām aṣṭānām siddhīnām śāstra antare saṃjñāḥ kṛtāḥ tāram sutāram tāratāram pramodam pramuditam pramodamānam ramyakam sadāpramuditam iti
translated: In another treatise, these eight perfections are given the names Tāra, Su-tāra, Tāra-tāra, Pramoda, Pramuditā, Pramodamāna, Ramyaka, and Sadā-pramuditā.

original: āsāṃ viparyayāt budderbandhā ye viparītāsta aśaktau nikṣiptā yathātāramasutāramatāratāramityādidraṣṭavyamaśaktibhedā
analyzed: āsām viparyayāt buddeḥ bandhāḥ ye viparītāḥ te aśaktau nikṣiptāḥ yathā a tāram asutāram atāratāram ityādi draṣṭavyam aśakti bhedā
translated: These, being the opposite of the eight perfections, are the eight opposite bonds of the intellect, placed in incapacity, as Tāra, Asutāra, Atāra-tāra, etc., should be seen. The divisions of incapacity

analyzed: aṣṭāviṃśatiḥ uktāḥ te saha buddhi bandhaiḥ ekādaśa indriya bandhāḥ iti
translated: are said to be twenty-eight, along with the bonds of the intellect. The bonds of the eleven senses are thus.

original: tatra tuṣṭiviparyayā nava siddhīnāṃ viparyayā aṣṭau evamete saptadaśa buddhibandhā
analyzed: tatra tuṣṭi viparyayāḥ nava siddhīnām viparyayāḥ aṣṭau evam ete saptadaśa buddhi bandhā
translated: Among them, the nine opposite of contentment and the eight opposite of the perfections, thus these seventeen are the bonds of the intellect.🔽Along with these, the twenty-eight divisions of incapacity are mentioned later. Thus, the enumeration and

original: etaiḥ sahendriyabandhā aṣṭāviṃśatiraśaktibhedāḥ paścāt kathitā iti viparyayāśaktituṣṭisiddhīnāmevoddeśo🔽nirdeśaśca kṛta iti /
analyzed: etaiḥ saha indriya bandhāḥ aṣṭāviṃśatiḥ aśakti bhedāḥ paścāt kathitāḥ iti viparyaya aśakti tuṣṭi siddhīnām eva uddeśaḥ  nirdeśaḥ ca kṛtaḥ iti
translated: explanation are given only of the opposite, incapacity, contentment, and perfection.

original: kiṃ cānyat siddheḥ pūrvo 'ṅkuśastrividhaḥ siddheḥ pūrvā yā viparyayāśaktituṣṭayastā
analyzed: kim ca anyat siddheḥ pūrvaḥ ṅkuśaḥ trividhaḥ siddheḥ pūrvāḥ yāḥ viparyaya aśakti tuṣṭayaḥ tāḥ
translated: What else? The three-fold goad is prior to perfection. The opposite of contentment and incapacity, which are prior to perfection,

original: eva siddheraṃkuśastadbhedādevaṃ trividho yathā hastī gṛhītāṃkuśena vaśo bhavatyeva
analyzed: eva siddheḥ aṃkuśaḥ tad bhedāt evam trividhaḥ yathā hastī gṛhīta aṃkuśena vaśaḥ bhavati eva
translated: are themselves the goad of perfection. It is thus threefold due to its divisions. Just as an elephant becomes obedient when seized by the goad,🔽so the mind becomes obedient when seized by the goad of the three-fold knowledge.

original: viparyayāśaktituṣṭibhirgṛhīto loko 'jñānamāpnoti tasmādetāḥ parityajya siddhiḥ sevyā
analyzed: viparyaya aśakti tuṣṭibhiḥ gṛhītaḥ lokaḥ jñānam āpnoti tasmāt etāḥ parityajya siddhiḥ sevyā
translated: The world, seized by error, incapacity, and contentment, attains ignorance. Therefore, abandoning these, success should be served.

analyzed: sa siddheḥ tattva jñānam utpadyate tat mokṣaḥ iti
translated: From success, the knowledge of reality arises. That is liberation.

original: atha yaduktaṃ bhāvairadhivāsitaṃ liṃgaṃ tatra bhāvā dharmādayo 'ṣṭāvuktā buddhipariṇāmā
analyzed: atha yat uktam bhāvaiḥ adhivāsitam liṃgam tatra bhāvāḥ dharma ādayaḥ ṣṭau uktāḥ buddhi pariṇāmā
translated: Now, it was said that the Linga is imbued with the Bhavas. There, the Bhavas, Dharma etc., are said to be eight, transformations of intellect.

original: viparyayāśaktituṣṭisiddhipariṇatāḥ sa bhāvākhyaḥ pratyayasargaḥ liṃgaṃ ca tanmātrasargaścaturdaśabhūtaparyanta
analyzed: viparyaya aśakti tuṣṭi siddhi pariṇatāḥ sa bhāva ākhyaḥ pratyaya sargaḥ liṃgam ca tanmātra sargaḥ caturdaśa bhūta paryanta
translated: They are transformed into error, incapacity, contentment, and success. That is the Bhava-named mental creation. And the Linga, and the Tanmatra creation, up to the fourteen elements,

analyzed: uktaḥ tatra ekena eva sargeṇa puruṣa artha siddhau kim ubhayavidha sargeṇa iti atas āha
translated: are said. There, when the purpose of the Spirit is accomplished by one creation alone, what is the use of both kinds of creation? Therefore, it is said:

original: na vinā bhāvairliṅgaṃ na vinā liṅgena bhāvanirvṛttiḥ /
analyzed: na vinā bhāvaiḥ liṅgam na vinā liṅgena bhāva nirvṛttiḥ
translated: Without the Bhavas, there is no Linga. Without the Linga, there is no manifestation of the Bhavas.

analyzed: liṅga ākhyaḥ bhāva ākhyaḥ tasmāt vividhaḥ pravarttate sargaḥ
translated: Therefore, the creation proceeds in two ways, called Linga and Bhava.

original: bhāvaiḥ pratyayasargairvinā liṃgaṃ na tanmātrasargo na pūrvapūrvasaṃskārādṛṣṭakāritatvāduttarottaradehalambhasya
analyzed: bhāvaiḥ pratyaya sargaiḥ vinā liṃgam na tanmātra sargaḥ na pūrva pūrva saṃskāra adṛṣṭa kārita tvāt uttarottara deha lambhasya
translated: Without the Bhavas, the mental creation, there is no Linga, the Tanmatra creation. Because the attainment of the subsequent body is caused by the unseen impressions of the previous ones.

original: liṃgena tanmātrasargeṇa ca vinā bhāvanirvṛttirna sthūlasūkṣmadehasādhyatvāddharmāderanāditvācca🔽sargasya bījāṃkurāvanyonyāśrayau na doṣāya tattajjātīyāpekṣitatve 'pi tattadvyaktīnāṃ
analyzed: liṃgena tanmātra sargeṇa ca vinā bhāva nirvṛttiḥ na sthūla sūkṣma deha sādhya tvāt dharma ādeḥ anādi tvāt ca  sargasya bīja aṃkurau anyonya āśrayau na doṣāya tad tad jātīya apekṣita tve pi tad tad vyaktīnām
translated: Without the Linga (subtle body) and the mere creation (of the gross body), there is no accomplishment of existence, because Dharma etc. are accomplished by the gross and subtle bodies, and because the creation is beginningless.

original: parasparānapekṣitvāttasmādbhāvākhyo liṃgākhyaśca dvividhaḥ pravarttate sarga iti // //
analyzed: paraspara anapekṣi tvāt tasmāt bhāva ākhyaḥ liṃga ākhyaḥ ca dvividhaḥ pravarttate sargaḥ iti
translated: The seed and sprout are mutually dependent, but that does not cause a fault, because even though they require each other of their own kind, the individual manifestations are mutually independent. Therefore, the creation is of two kinds: Bhava (gross creation) and Linga (subtle creation).

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: Moreover, what else?

analyzed: aṣṭa vikalpaḥ daivaḥ tairyagyonaḥ ca pañcadhā bhavati
translated: The divine creation is of eight kinds, and the animal creation is of five kinds.

analyzed: mānuṣyaḥ ca ekavidhaḥ samāsatas bhautikaḥ sargaḥ
translated: In brief, the creation of matter is of one kind, human.

original: tatra daivamaṣṭaprakāraṃ brāhmaṃ prājāpatyaṃ saumyamaindraṃ gāndharvaṃ yākṣaṃ rākṣasaṃ paiśācamiti /
analyzed: tatra daivam aṣṭa prakāram brāhmam prājāpatyam saumyam aindram gāndharvam yākṣam rākṣasam paiśācam iti
translated: There, the divine creation is of eight kinds: Brahmic, Prajapatya, Saumya, Aindriya, Gandharva, Yaksha, Rakshasa, and Paisacha.

analyzed: paśu mṛga pakṣi sarīsṛpa sthāvarāṇi bhūtāni eva pañcavidhaḥ tairaḥ ca
translated: The five kinds of animals are the animals, deer, birds, reptiles, and immobile beings.

analyzed: mānuṣa yoniḥ ekā eva iti caturdaśa bhūtāni
translated: The human birth is of one kind only. Thus, there are fourteen kinds of beings.

original: triṣvapi lokeṣu guṇatrayamasti tatra kasmin kimadhikamucyate /
analyzed: triṣu api lokeṣu guṇatrayam asti tatra kasmin kim adhikam ucyate
translated: In all the three worlds, there are three qualities. In which one is said to be predominant?

analyzed: ūrdhvam sattva viśālaḥ tamaḥ viśālaḥ ca mūlataḥ sargaḥ
translated: The creation above is vast with sattva, and vast with tamas at the root.

analyzed: madhye rajaḥ viśālaḥ brahma ādi stamba paryantaḥ
translated: In the middle, vast with rajas, from Brahma to the lowest plants.

original: ūrddhvamityaṣṭasu devasthāneṣu sattvaviśālaṃ sattvavistāraḥ sattvotkaṭa ūrddhvasattva iti /
analyzed: ūrddhvam iti aṣṭasu devasthāneṣu sattva viśālam sattva vistāraḥ sattva utkaṭaḥ ūrddhva sattvaḥ iti
translated: Above means in the eight divine abodes, vast with sattva, meaning the expansion of sattva, the predominance of sattva, the sattva above.

analyzed: tatra api rajaḥ tamasī staḥ
translated: Even there, rajas and tamas exist.

original: tamoviśālo mūlataḥ paśvādiṣu sthāvarānteṣu sarvaḥsargastamasādhikyena vyāptastatrāpi sattvarajasī staḥ /
analyzed: tamaḥ viśālaḥ mūlatas paśu ādiṣu sthāvara anteṣu sarvaḥ sargaḥ tamaḥ ādhikyena vyāptaḥ tatra api sattva rajasī staḥ
translated: Vast with tamas at the root, all creation from animals to plants is pervaded by the predominance of tamas. Even there, sattva and rajas exist.

original: madhye mānuṣye raja utkaṭaṃ tatrāpi sattvatamasī vidyete tasmādduḥkhaprāyā manuṣyāḥ /
analyzed: madhye mānuṣye rajaḥ utkaṭam tatra api sattva tamasī vidyete tasmāt duḥkha prāyāḥ manuṣyāḥ
translated: In the middle, among humans, rajas is predominant. Even there, sattva and tamas are found. Therefore, humans are mostly miserable.

analyzed: evam brahma ādi stamba paryantaḥ brahma ādi sthāvara antaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, from Brahma to the lowest plants, meaning from Brahma to the lowest immobile beings.

original: evamabhautikaḥ sargo liṃgasargo bhāvasargo bhūtasargo daivamānuṣatairyagyonaya ityeṣaḥ pradhānakṛtaḥ ṣoḍaśaḥ sargaḥ // //
analyzed: evam abhautikaḥ sargaḥ liṃga sargaḥ bhāva sargaḥ bhūta sargaḥ daiva mānuṣa tairyagyonayaḥ iti eṣaḥ pradhāna kṛtaḥ ṣoḍaśaḥ sargaḥ  /
translated: Thus, the non-material creation, the creation of the linga, the creation of existence, the creation of the elements, the divine, human, and animal wombs - this is the sixteenfold creation produced by prakriti.

original: tatra jarāmaraṇakṛtaṃ duḥkhaṃ prāpnoti cetanaḥ puruṣaḥ /
analyzed: tatra jarā maraṇa kṛtam duḥkham prāpnoti cetanaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: There, the conscious Purusha experiences suffering caused by old age and death.

analyzed: liṅgasya avinivṛtteḥ tasmāt duḥkham samāsena
translated: Because the linga is not destroyed, therefore suffering is briefly...

original: tatreti teṣu devamānuṣatiryagyoniṣu jarākṛtaṃ maraṇakṛtaṃ caiva duḥkhaṃ cetanaḥ caitanyavān puruṣaḥ prāpnoti na pradhānaṃ na buddhirnāhaṃkāro
analyzed: tatra iti teṣu deva mānuṣa tiryagyoniṣu jarā kṛtam maraṇa kṛtam ca eva duḥkham cetanaḥ caitanyavān puruṣaḥ prāpnoti na pradhānam na buddhiḥ na ahaṃkāraḥ
translated: There, in those divine, human, and animal wombs, the conscious person, endowed with consciousness, experiences the suffering caused by old age and death, not the primordial nature, not the intellect, not the ego,

analyzed: na tanmātrāṇi indriyāṇi mahābhūtāni ca
translated: not the subtle elements, not the senses, not the great elements.

original: kiyantaṃ kālaṃ puruṣo duḥkhaṃ prāpnotīti tadvivinakti /
analyzed: kiyantam kālam puruṣaḥ duḥkham prāpnoti iti tat vivinakti
translated: For how long does the person experience suffering? He distinguishes that.

analyzed: liṃgasya avinivṛtteḥ yat tat mahat ādi liṃga śarīreṇa āviśya tatra vyaktībhavati tat yāvat nivarttate
translated: As long as the linga (subtle body) is not withdrawn, that which becomes manifest there by entering the linga body consisting of mahat etc., as long as that is not withdrawn,

original: saṃsāraśarīramiti saṃkṣepeṇa triṣu sthāneṣu puruṣo jarāmaraṇakṛtaṃ duḥkhaṃ prāpnoti
analyzed: saṃsāra śarīram iti saṃkṣepeṇa triṣu sthāneṣu puruṣaḥ jarā maraṇa kṛtam duḥkham prāpnoti
translated: the body of worldly existence. In brief, the person experiences the suffering caused by old age and death in three places.

analyzed: liṃgasya avinivṛtteḥ liṃgasya vinivṛttim yāvat
translated: As long as the linga is not withdrawn, until the withdrawal of the linga.

analyzed: liṃga nivṛttau mokṣaḥ mokṣa prāptau na asti duḥkham iti
translated: When the linga is withdrawn, there is liberation. When liberation is attained, there is no suffering.

original: tatpunaḥ kena nivarttate yadā pañcaviṃśatitattvajñānaṃ syāt sattvapuruṣānyathākhyātilakṣaṇamidaṃ
analyzed: tat punar kena nivarttate yadā pañcaviṃśati tattva jñānam syāt sattva puruṣa anyathā khyāti lakṣaṇam idam
translated: By what is that again withdrawn? When there is the knowledge of the twenty-five principles, characterized by the non-apprehension of the difference between sattva (purity) and purusha (soul),

original: pradhānamiyaṃ buddhirayamahaṃkāra imāni pañcatanmātrāṇyekādaśendriyāṇi pañca mahābhūtāni
analyzed: pradhānam iyam buddhiḥ ayam ahaṃkāraḥ imāni pañca tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi pañca mahābhūtāni
translated: this is prakriti (primordial matter), this is buddhi (intellect), this is ahamkara (ego), these are the five tanmatras (subtle elements), the eleven indriyas (sense organs), and the five mahabhuta (great elements),

original: yebhyo 'nyaḥ puruṣo visadṛśa ityevaṃ jñānālliṃganivṛttistato mokṣa iti // //
analyzed: yebhyaḥ nyaḥ puruṣaḥ visadṛśaḥ iti evam jñānāt liṃga nivṛttiḥ tatas mokṣaḥ iti
translated: From the knowledge that there is another person different from these, there is cessation of the signs, and from that, liberation.

analyzed: pravṛtteḥ kim nimittam ārabhyaḥ iti ucyate
translated: What is the cause of activity? It is said to begin from this.

analyzed: iti eṣa prakṛti kṛtaḥ mahat ādi viṣaya bhūta paryantaḥ
translated: Thus, this creation beginning with Mahat and ending with the gross elements is due to Prakṛti.

analyzed: prati puruṣa vimokṣa artham sva arthe iva para arthe ārambhaḥ
translated: The beginning is for the liberation of each individual, as if for one's own sake, for the sake of others.

original: ityeṣa parisamāptau nirddeśe ca prakṛtivikṛtau prakṛtikaraṇe prakṛtikriyāyāṃ ya ārambho
analyzed: iti eṣa parisamāptau nirddeśe ca prakṛti vikṛtau prakṛti karaṇe prakṛti kriyāyām yaḥ ārambhaḥ
translated: Thus, this is the completion and instruction of Prakṛti and Vikṛti, the creation by Prakṛti, the action by Prakṛti. The beginning is

analyzed: mahat ādi viśeṣa bhūta paryantaḥ prakṛteḥ mahān mahataḥ haṃkāraḥ tasmāt tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi
translated: from Mahat up to the gross elements. From Prakṛti comes Mahat, from Mahat comes Ahamkāra, from that the Tanmātras and the eleven sense organs.

original: tanmātrebhyaḥ pañcamahābhūtānītyeṣaḥ pratipuruṣavimokṣārthaṃ puruṣaṃ prati devamanuṣyatiryagbhāvaṃ🔽gatānāṃ vimokṣārthamārambhaḥ kathaṃ svārtha iva parārthamārambhaḥ yathā kaścit svārthaṃ
analyzed: tanmātrebhyaḥ pañca mahābhūtāni iti eṣaḥ prati puruṣa vimokṣa artham puruṣam prati deva manuṣya tiryak bhāvam  gatānām vimokṣa artham ārambhaḥ katham sva arthe iva para artham ārambhaḥ yathā kaścid sva artham
translated: From the Tanmātras come the five gross elements. This creation is for the liberation of each individual, for the liberation of those who have become gods, humans, and animals.

analyzed: tyaktvā mitra kāryāṇi karoti evam pradhānam
translated: How is the beginning as if for one's own sake for the sake of others? Just as someone abandons his own sake and does the work of friends, so does Prakṛti.

original: puruṣo 'tra pradhānasya na kiñcit pratyupakāraṃ karoti /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ u tra pradhānasya na kiñcid pratyupakāram karoti
translated: The Puruṣa does not do any return service to Prakṛti here.

original: svārtha iva na ca svāthaḥ parārtha evārthaḥ śabdādiviṣayopalabdhirguṇapuruṣāntaropalabdhiśca
analyzed: sva arthaḥ iva na ca sva athaḥ para arthaḥ eva arthaḥ śabda ādi viṣaya upalabdhiḥ guṇa puruṣa antara upalabdhiḥ ca
translated: And the purpose is not for its own sake, but only for the sake of another. The purpose is the perception of objects like sound, and the perception of the difference between the qualities and the puruṣa.

original: triṣu lokeṣu śabdādiviṣayaiḥ puruṣā yojayitavyā ante ca mokṣeṇeti pradhānasya pravṛttistathā coktam /
analyzed: triṣu lokeṣu śabda ādi viṣayaiḥ puruṣāḥ yojayitavyāḥ ante ca mokṣeṇa iti pradhānasya pravṛttiḥ tathā ca uktam
translated: In the three worlds, the puruṣa is to be united with objects like sound, and in the end with liberation. Thus the activity of the pradhāna is stated.

original: kumbhavat pradhānaṃ puruṣārthaṃ kṛtvā nivarttata iti // //
analyzed: kumbha vat pradhānam puruṣa artham kṛtvā nivarttate iti
translated: Just as a pot, having served its purpose for the puruṣa, ceases, so does the pradhāna.

original: atrocyate 'cetanaṃ pradhānaṃ cetanaḥ puruṣa iti mayā triṣu lokeṣu śabdādibhirviṣayaiḥ puruṣo yojyo 'nte mokṣaḥ karttavya iti kathaṃ cetanavat 🔽pravṛtiḥ /
analyzed: atra ucyate cetanam pradhānam cetanaḥ puruṣaḥ iti mayā triṣu lokeṣu śabda ādibhiḥ viṣayaiḥ puruṣaḥ yojyaḥ nte mokṣaḥ karttavyaḥ iti katham cetana vat  pravṛtiḥ
translated: To this it is said: The pradhāna is insentient, the puruṣa is sentient. How can there be activity like that of a sentient being, thinking 'I shall unite the puruṣa with objects like sound in the three worlds, and in the end accomplish its liberation'?

original: satyaṃ kiṃtvacetanānāmapi pravṛttirdṛṣṭā nivṛttiśca yasmādityāha /🔽vatsavivṛddhinimittaṃ kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttirajñasya /
analyzed: satyam kiṃtu acetanānām api pravṛttiḥ dṛṣṭā nivṛttiḥ ca yasmāt iti āha  vatsa vivṛddhi nimittam kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttiḥ ajñasya
translated: It is true, but the activity and cessation of insentient things are also seen. Therefore it is said:

analyzed: puruṣa vimokṣa nimittam tathā pravṛttiḥ pradhānasya
translated: Just as milk has activity for the purpose of nourishing the calf, so the activity of the pradhāna is for the purpose of liberating the puruṣa.

original: yathā tṛṇādikaṃ gavā bhakṣitaṃ kṣīrabhāvena pariṇamya vatsavivṛddhiṃ karoti puṣṭe ca vatse nivarttata evaṃ puruṣavimokṣanimittaṃ pradhānam
analyzed: yathā tṛṇa ādikam gavā bhakṣitam kṣīra bhāvena pariṇamya vatsa vivṛddhim karoti puṣṭe ca vatse nivarttate evam puruṣa vimokṣa nimittam pradhānam
translated: Just as grass etc. eaten by a cow is transformed into milk and nourishes the calf, and when the calf is nourished, it ceases, in the same way, the primordial matter acts for the liberation of the soul.

analyzed: ajñasya pravṛttiḥ ita
translated: The activity of the ignorant is for that purpose.

analyzed: kiṃca  autsukya nivṛtti artham yathā kriyāsu pravartate lokaḥ
translated: And what else?🔽Just as people engage in actions for the sake of removing their eagerness,

analyzed: puruṣasya vimokṣa artham pravartate tadvat avyaktam
translated: in the same way, the unmanifest primordial matter acts for the liberation of the soul.

original: yathā loka ityaustukye sati tasya nivṛttyarthaṃ kriyāsu pravarttate gamanāgamanakriyāsu🔽kṛtakāryo nivarttate tathā puruṣasya vimokṣārthaṃ śabdādiviṣayopabhogopalabdhilakṣaṇaṃ
analyzed: yathā loke iti austukye sati tasya nivṛtti artham kriyāsu pravarttate gamana āgamana kriyāsu  kṛta kāryaḥ nivarttate tathā puruṣasya vimokṣa artham śabda ādi viṣaya upabhoga upalabdhi lakṣaṇam
translated: Just as people, when eager, engage in actions such as going and coming for the sake of removing that eagerness,🔽and when their purpose is accomplished, they cease, in the same way, primordial matter, having accomplished the twofold purpose of the soul - the purpose characterized by the experience of the enjoyment of objects like sound, and the purpose characterized by the realization of the difference between the qualities and the soul,

original: guṇapuruṣāntaropalabdhilakṣaṇaṃ ca dvividhamapi puruṣārthaṃ kṛtvā pradhānaṃ nivartate // //
analyzed: guṇa puruṣa antara upalabdhi lakṣaṇam ca dvividham api puruṣa artham kṛtvā pradhānam nivartate  /
translated: ceases its activity.

original: kiṃ cānyat /🔽raṅgasya darśayitvā nivartate nartakī yathā nṛtyāt /
analyzed: kim ca anyat  raṅgasya darśayitvā nivartate nartakī yathā nṛtyāt
translated: And what else?🔽Just as a dancer, having displayed her dance, ceases,

analyzed: puruṣasya tathā ātmānam prakāśya nivartate prakṛtiḥ
translated: in the same way, primordial nature, having revealed the self to the soul, ceases.

analyzed: yathā narttakī śṛṅgāra ādi rasauḥ itihāsa ādi bhāvaiḥ ca nibaddha gīta vāditra vṛttāni raṅgasya
translated: Just as a dancer, through the sentiments of love, heroism, etc., and the moods of mirth, etc., presents on the stage the various episodes of songs and instrumental music,

original: darśayitvā kṛtakāryā nṛtyānnivarttate tathā prakṛtirapi puruṣasyātmānaṃ prakāśya
analyzed: darśayitvā kṛta kāryā nṛtyāt nivarttate tathā prakṛtiḥ api puruṣasya ātmānam prakāśya
translated: Just as a dancer, having displayed on the stage the songs, musical instruments, and actions connected with the sentiments of love, heroism, etc., and having accomplished her purpose, turns back from dancing, so does Nature, having revealed the Self of the Spirit,

analyzed: buddhi ahaṃkāra tanmātra indiya mahābhūta bhedena nivartate
translated: turns back by means of the distinctions of intellect, ego, subtle elements, senses, and gross elements.

analyzed: katham kaḥ vā syāt nivarttakaḥ hetuḥ tat āha
translated: How and what would be the cause of turning back? He says:

analyzed: nānāvidhaiḥ upāyaiḥ upakāriṇī anupakāriṇaḥ puṃsaḥ
translated: The Nature, which is the helper by various means, of the Spirit who is not a helper,

analyzed: guṇavatī aguṇasya sataḥ tasya artham apārthakam carati
translated: acts for the sake of that qualityless and existent one, though the purpose is futile.

original: nānāvidhairupāyaiḥ prakṛtiḥ puruṣasyopakāriṇyanupakāriṇaḥ puṃsaḥ kathaṃ devamānuṣatiryagbhāvena
analyzed: nānāvidhaiḥ upāyaiḥ prakṛtiḥ puruṣasya upakāriṇī anupakāriṇaḥ puṃsaḥ katham deva mānuṣa tiryak bhāvena
translated: The Nature, by various means, is the helper of the Spirit. How is it that of the Spirit who is not a helper? By means of the states of gods, humans, and animals,

analyzed: sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka bhāvena śabda ādi viṣaya bhāvena evam nānāvidhaiḥ upāyaiḥ ātmānam prakāśya aham anyā
translated: by means of the states consisting of pleasure, pain, and delusion, by means of the objects such as sound, etc., in this way, having revealed itself by various means, it turns back, saying I am different, You are different.

original: tvamanya iti nivarttate 'to nityasya tasyārthamapārthaṃ kurute carati ca yathā kaścit
analyzed: tvam anyaḥ iti nivarttate nityasya tasya artham apārtham kurute carati ca yathā kaścid
translated: Therefore, it makes futile the purpose of that which is eternal. It acts and moves, just as someone

original: paropakārī sarvasyopakurute nātmanaḥ pratyupakāramīhata evaṃ prakṛtiḥ puruṣārthaṃ
analyzed: para upakārī sarvasya upakurute na ātmanaḥ pratyupakāram īhate evam prakṛtiḥ puruṣa artham
translated: One who benefits others benefits all, not seeking reciprocation for oneself. Thus, by nature, one acts for the purpose of the Self.

analyzed: kurute karoti apārthakam
translated: One acts for the sake of others, not for one's own sake.

original: paścāduktamātmānaṃ prakāśya nivarttate nivṛtta ca kiṃ karotītyāha /
analyzed: paścāt uktam ātmānam prakāśya nivarttate nivṛtta ca kim karoti iti āha
translated: Having revealed the Self that was previously spoken of, it ceases. Having ceased, what does it do? He says:

original: prakṛteḥ sukumārataraṃ na kiñcidastīti me matirbhavati /
analyzed: prakṛteḥ sukumārataram na kiñcid asti iti me matiḥ bhavati
translated: I think there is nothing more delicate than Nature.

original: yā dṛṣṭāsmīti punarna darśanamupaiti puruṣasya // //🔽loke prakṛteḥ sukumārataraṃ na kiñcidastītyevaṃ me matirbhavati yena parārtha evaṃ
analyzed: yā dṛṣṭā asmi iti punar na darśanam upaiti puruṣasya  loke prakṛteḥ sukumārataram na kiñcid asti iti evam me matiḥ bhavati yena parārthaḥ evam
translated: Having been seen, it does not again come within the range of vision of the Spirit.

original: matirutpannā kasmādahamanena puruṣeṇa dṛṣṭāsmītyasya puṃso punardarśanaṃ nopaiti
analyzed: matiḥ utpannā kasmāt aham anena puruṣeṇa dṛṣṭā asmi iti asya punar darśanam na upaiti
translated: In the world, I think there is nothing more delicate than Nature, by which this idea arises for the sake of others. Why is it that I have been seen by this Spirit? Again, the vision of this Spirit does not come within the range of vision of the Spirit.

analyzed: puruṣasya adarśanam upayāti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it goes out of the range of vision of the Spirit.

analyzed: tatra sukumārataram varṇayati
translated: There, he describes what is more delicate.

analyzed: īśvaram kāraṇam bruvate
translated: They speak of God as the cause.

original: ajo janturanīśo 'yamātmā naḥ sukhaduḥkhayorīśvaraprerito gacchet svargaṃ narakameva vā //
analyzed: ajaḥ jantuḥ anīśaḥ yam ātmā naḥ sukha duḥkhayoḥ īśvara preritaḥ gacchet svargam narakam eva vā
translated: This unborn creature, powerless, is our Self. Driven by God, it would go to heaven or even hell, due to happiness and sorrow.

analyzed: apare svabhāva kāraṇikām bruvate
translated: Others speak of it as being caused by inherent nature.

original: kena śuklīkṛtā haṃsā mayūrāḥ kena citritāḥ /
analyzed: kena śuklīkṛtāḥ haṃsāḥ mayūrāḥ kena citritāḥ
translated: By what are swans made white, peacocks variegated?

original: svabhāvenaiveti /🔽atra sāṃkhyācāryā āhuḥ nirguṇatvādīśvarasya kathaṃ saguṇataḥ prajā jāyeran kathaṃ
analyzed: svabhāvena eva iti  atra sāṃkhya ācāryāḥ āhuḥ nirguṇa tvāt īśvarasya katham sa guṇataḥ prajāḥ jāyeran katham
translated: By their own nature alone.

original: vā puruṣānnirguṇādeva tasmāt prakṛteryujyate yathā śuklebhyastantubhyaḥ śukla eva
analyzed: vā puruṣāt nirguṇāt eva tasmāt prakṛteḥ yujyate yathā śuklebhyaḥ tantubhyaḥ śuklaḥ eva
translated: Here the Sāṃkhya teachers say: If God is without qualities, how can beings be born with qualities? Or how can they be born from the qualityless Puruṣa? Therefore it is reasonable that from Prakṛti, just as a white cloth comes from white threads,

analyzed: paṭaḥ bhavati kṛṣṇebhyaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ eva iti
translated: a black one from black ones.

original: evaṃ triguṇāt pradhānāt trayo lokāstriguṇāḥ samutpannā iti gamyate /
analyzed: evam triguṇāt pradhānāt trayaḥ lokāḥ triguṇāḥ samutpannāḥ iti gamyate
translated: Thus it is understood that the three worlds, consisting of the three qualities, originate from the three-fold Prakṛti.

analyzed: nirguṇaḥ īśvaraḥ sa guṇānām lokānām tasmāt utpattiḥ ayuktā iti
translated: The origin of the worlds with qualities from the qualityless God is unreasonable.

analyzed: anena puruṣaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this, the Puruṣa is explained.

analyzed: tathā keṣāṃcid kālaḥ kāraṇam iti uktam ca
translated: Similarly, for some, time is said to be the cause.

original: kālaḥ pañcāsti bhūtāni kālaḥ saṃharate jagat /
analyzed: kālaḥ pañca asti bhūtāni kālaḥ saṃharate jagat
translated: Time is the five elements, time destroys the world,

original: kālaḥ supteṣu jāgartti kālo hi duratikramaḥ //
analyzed: kālaḥ supteṣu jāgartti kālaḥ hi duratikramaḥ
translated: time is awake when all are asleep, time is indeed irresistible.

original: vyaktamavyaktapuruṣāstrayaḥ padārthāstena kālo 'ntarbhūto 'sti sa vyaktaḥ sarvakartṛtvāt kālasyāpi pradhānameva kāraṇaṃ svabhāvo 'pyatraiva
analyzed: vyaktam avyakta puruṣāḥ trayaḥ padārthāḥ tena kālaḥ sti sa vyaktaḥ sarva kartṛ tvāt kālasya api pradhānam eva kāraṇam svabhāvaḥ atra eva
translated: The three categories are the manifest, the unmanifest, and the Puruṣa. Time is included in that. The manifest is the cause of time, because it is the agent of all. Even the nature of time is the Prakṛti itself.

analyzed: līnaḥ tasmāt kālaḥ na kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, time is not the cause.

analyzed: na api svabhāvaḥ iti
translated: Nor is it the intrinsic nature.

original: tasmāt prakṛtireva kāraṇaṃ na prakṛteḥ kāraṇāntaramastīti /
analyzed: tasmāt prakṛtiḥ eva kāraṇam na prakṛteḥ kāraṇa antaram asti iti
translated: Therefore, the intrinsic nature itself is the cause, and there is no other cause for the intrinsic nature.

analyzed: na punar darśanam upayāti puruṣasya
translated: It does not appear again to the person.

original: ataḥ prakṛteḥ sukumārataraṃ subhogyataraṃ na kiñcidīśvarādikāraṇamastīti me matirbhavati // //
analyzed: atas prakṛteḥ sukumārataram su bhogyataram na kiñcid īśvara ādi kāraṇam asti iti me matiḥ bhavati  /
translated: Therefore, I think there is no cause such as God that is more delicate or more enjoyable than the intrinsic nature.

analyzed: tathā ca śloke rūḍham
translated: And it is well-established in the verse in this way.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ muktaḥ puruṣaḥ saṃsārī iti coditā iti āha
translated: When it is said that the liberated person is the transmigrating person, he says:

original: tasmānna badhyate nāpi mucyate nāpi saṃsarati kaścit /
analyzed: tasmāt na badhyate na api mucyate na api saṃsarati kaścid
translated: Therefore, no one is bound, nor is anyone liberated, nor does anyone transmigrate.

original: saṃsarati badhyate mucyate ca nānāśrayā prakṛtiḥ // //
analyzed: saṃsarati badhyate mucyate ca nānā āśrayā prakṛtiḥ
translated: The intrinsic nature, having various bases, transmigrates, is bound, and is liberated.

original: tasmāt kāraṇāt puruṣo na badhyate nāpi mucyate nāpi saṃsarati yasmāt kāraṇāt prakṛtireva
analyzed: tasmāt kāraṇāt puruṣaḥ na badhyate na api mucyate na api saṃsarati yasmāt kāraṇāt prakṛtiḥ eva
translated: For that reason, the person is not bound, nor is he liberated, nor does he transmigrate, because the intrinsic nature itself

analyzed: nānā āśrayāḥ daiva mānuṣa tiryagyoni āśrayāḥ buddhi ahaṃkāra tanmātra indriya bhūta sva rūpeṇa
translated: has various bases, having the nature of divine, human, and animal births, in the form of intellect, ego, subtle elements, senses, and elements

analyzed: badhyate mucyate saṃsarati ca iti
translated: is bound, liberated, and transmigrates.

original: atha mukta eva svabhāvāt sa sarvagataśca kathaṃ saṃsaratyaprāptaprāpaṇārthaṃ saṃsaraṇamiti
analyzed: atha muktaḥ eva svabhāvāt sa sarva gataḥ ca katham saṃsarati aprāpta prāpaṇa artham saṃsaraṇam iti
translated: Now, if the Self is indeed liberated by nature, and all-pervading, how does it transmigrate, since transmigration is for the purpose of attaining what is not yet attained?

original: tena puruṣo badhyate puruṣo mucyate saṃsarati vyapadiśyate yena saṃsāritvaṃ na vidyate
analyzed: tena puruṣaḥ badhyate puruṣaḥ mucyate saṃsarati vyapadiśyate yena saṃsāri tvam na vidyate
translated: By that [means], the person is bound, the person is liberated, the person transmigrates, and is designated as one who transmigrates, although transmigration does not exist.

analyzed: sattva puruṣa anta jñānāt tattvam puruṣasya abhivyajyate
translated: From the knowledge of the difference between the Self and the not-Self, the true nature of the Self becomes manifest.

original: tadabhivyakto kevalaḥ śuddho muktaḥ svarūpapratiṣṭhaḥ puruṣa iti /
analyzed: kevalaḥ śuddhaḥ muktaḥ svarūpa pratiṣṭhaḥ puruṣaḥ iti
translated: When that [true nature] becomes manifest, the Self abides in its own nature, being alone, pure, liberated.

original: atra yadi puruṣasya bandho nasti tato mokṣo 'pi nāsti /
analyzed: atra yadi puruṣasya bandhaḥ na asti tatas mokṣaḥ na asti
translated: Here, if the Self has no bondage, then liberation also does not exist.

original: atrocyate prakṛtirevātmānaṃ badhnāti mocayati ca yatra sūkṣmaśarīraṃ tanmātrakaṃ trividhakaraṇopetaṃ tat trividhena bandhena badhyate /
analyzed: atrā ucyate prakṛtiḥ eva ātmānam badhnāti mocayati ca yatra sūkṣmaśarīram tanmātrakam trividha karaṇa upetam tat trividhena bandhena badhyate
translated: Here it is said: Nature itself binds and liberates the Self. Where there is the subtle body consisting of the tanmatras and endowed with the three kinds of organs, it is bound by three kinds of bondage.

original: uktaṃ ca prākṛtena ca bandhena tathā vaikārikeṇa ca /
analyzed: uktam ca prākṛtena ca bandhena tathā vaikārikeṇa ca
translated: And it is said: By the bondage of Prakṛti, and likewise by that of Vikṛti,

analyzed: dākṣiṇena tṛtīyena baddhaḥ na anyena mucyate
translated: By the third, that of Dakṣiṇa, one is bound, not liberated by any other.

analyzed: tat sūkṣmam śarīram dharma adharmam saṃyuktam
translated: That subtle body is connected with Dharma and Adharma.

original: prakṛtiśca badhyate prakṛtiśca mucyate saṃsaratīti kathaṃ taducyate /
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ ca badhyate prakṛtiḥ ca mucyate saṃsarati iti katham tat ucyate
translated: And how is it said that Nature is bound, Nature is liberated, Nature transmigrates?

analyzed: rūpaiḥ saptabhiḥ evam badhnāti ātmānam ātmanā prakṛtiḥ
translated: Thus, Nature binds itself by seven forms.

analyzed: sā eva ca puruṣasya artham prati vimocayati eka rūpeṇa
translated: And it itself liberates the Spirit from the purpose of the Spirit by one form.

original: rūpaiḥ saptabhirevaitāni sapta procyante dharmo vairāgyamaiśvaryamadharmo 'jñānamavairāgyamanaiśvaryyametāni
analyzed: rūpaiḥ saptabhiḥ eva etāni sapta procyante dharmaḥ vairāgyam aiśvaryam adharmaḥ jñānam avairāgyam anaiśvaryam etāni
translated: By seven forms alone, these seven are said to be: Dharma, non-attachment, lordship, adharma, ignorance, attachment, and non-lordship. These are

original: prakṛteḥ saptarūpāṇi tairātmānaṃ svaṃ badhnāti prakṛtirātmānaṃ svameva saiva prakṛtiḥ
analyzed: prakṛteḥ sapta rūpāṇi taiḥ ātmānam svam badhnāti prakṛtiḥ ātmānam svam eva sā eva prakṛtiḥ
translated: the seven forms of Nature. By them, Nature binds its own self. Nature itself

original: puruṣasyārthaḥ puruṣārthaḥ karttavya iti vimocayatyātmānamekarūpeṇa jñānena // //
analyzed: puruṣasya arthaḥ puruṣa arthaḥ karttavyaḥ iti vimocayati ātmānam eka rūpeṇa jñānena
translated: liberates the Spirit from the purpose of the Spirit by one form, by knowledge.

analyzed: katham tat jñānam utpadyate
translated: How does that knowledge arise?

analyzed: evam tattva abhyāsāt na asmi na me na aham iti apariśeṣam
translated: Thus, by the practice of the truth, I am not, this is not mine, this is not I, without remainder,

original: aviparyayādviśuddhaṃ kevalamutpadyate jñānam // //🔽evamuktena kramena pañcaviṃśatitattvālocanābhyāsādiyaṃ prakṛtirayaṃ puruṣa etāni
analyzed: aviparyayāt viśuddham kevalam utpadyate jñānam  evam uktena kramena pañcaviṃśati tattva ālocanā abhyāsāt iyam prakṛtiḥ ayam puruṣaḥ etāni
translated: pure, solitary knowledge arises, free from error.🔽In this way, by the practice of contemplating the twenty-five principles, the knowledge arises in the Spirit that this is Nature, this is the Spirit, these are

original: pañcatanmātrendriyamahābhūtānīti puruṣasya jñānamutpadyate nāsti nāhameva bhavāmi
analyzed: pañca tanmātra indriya mahābhūtāni iti puruṣasya jñānam utpadyate na asti na aham eva bhavāmi
translated: the five subtle elements, senses, and gross elements. I do not exist, I am not.

analyzed: na me mama śarīram tat yatas ham anyaḥ śarīram anyat na aham iti apariśeṣam ahaṃkāra rahitam apariśeṣam aviparyayāt viśuddham
translated: That is not my body, since I am one and the body is another. Without the remainder of the ego, without the remainder, pure by the absence of error,🔽pure by the absence of doubt due to the absence of error.

original: viparyayaḥ saṃśayo 'viparyayādasaṃśayādviśuddhaṃ kevalaṃ tadeva nānyadastīti mokṣakāraṇamutpadyate
analyzed: viparyayaḥ saṃśayaḥ viparyayāt asaṃśayāt viśuddham kevalam tat eva na anyat asti iti mokṣa kāraṇam utpadyate
translated: That alone is the cause of liberation, not anything else.

analyzed: abhivyajyate jñānam pañcaviṃśati tattva jñānam puruṣasya iti
translated: The knowledge of the twenty-five principles of the Purusha manifests.

analyzed: jñāne puruṣaḥ kim karoti  tena nivṛtta prasavām artha vaśāt sapta rūpa vinivṛttām
translated: What does the Purusha do with that knowledge?

analyzed: prakṛtim paśyati puruṣaḥ prekṣaka vat avasthitaḥ svasthaḥ
translated: By that, the Purusha sees Prakṛti, which has ceased to function, which has turned away from the seven forms by the force of its purpose,🔽remaining like a spectator, well-settled.

original: tena viśuddhena kevalajñānena puruṣaḥ prakṛtiṃ paśyati prekṣakavat prekṣakeṇa tulyamavasthitaḥ
analyzed: tena viśuddhena kevala jñānena puruṣaḥ prakṛtim paśyati prekṣaka vat prekṣakeṇa tulyam avasthitaḥ
translated: The Purusha sees Prakṛti with that pure, solitary knowledge, remaining like a spectator.

original: svastho yathā raṃgaprekṣako 'vasthito narttakīṃ paśyatiḥ svasthaḥ svasmiṃstiṣṭhati
analyzed: svasthaḥ yathā raṃga prekṣakaḥ vasthitaḥ narttakīm paśyatiḥ svasthaḥ svasmin tiṣṭhati
translated: Well-settled, like a spectator in the theater seeing the dancer, well-settled, remaining in itself.

analyzed: svasthaḥ sva sthāna sthitaḥ
translated: Well-settled, remaining in its own place.

original: kathaṃbhūtāṃ prakṛtiṃ nivṛttaprasavāṃ nivṛttaḥ buddhyahaṃkārakāryyānarthavaśāt saptarūpavinivṛttāṃ
analyzed: kathaṃbhūtām prakṛtim nivṛtta prasavām nivṛttaḥ buddhi ahaṃkāra kāryya anartha vaśāt sapta rūpa vinivṛttām
translated: What kind of Nature? One from whom the activity of creation has ceased, who has turned away from the seven forms due to the cessation of the undesirable results of intellect and ego.

analyzed: nivarttita ubhaya puruṣa prayojana vaśa ādyaiḥ saptabhiḥ rūpaiḥ dharma ādibhiḥ ātmānam badhnāti
translated: Due to the cessation of the purpose of both Purushas, by which seven forms beginning with Dharma one binds oneself.

original: tebhyaḥ saptabhyo rūpebhyo vinivṛttiṃ prakṛtiṃ paśyati // //
analyzed: tebhyaḥ saptabhyaḥ rūpebhyaḥ vinivṛttim prakṛtim paśyati
translated: He sees Nature from which those seven forms have turned away.

analyzed: kim ca
translated: Moreover,

analyzed: dṛṣṭā mayā iti upekṣakaḥ ekaḥ dṛṣṭā aham iti uparamati anyā
translated: One remains indifferent, thinking I have seen, the other ceases, thinking She has seen.

original: sati saṃyoge 'pi tayoḥ prayojanaṃ nāsti sargasya // //🔽raṃgastha iti yathā raṃgastha ityevamupekṣaka ekaḥ kevalaḥ śuddhaḥ puruṣastenāhaṃ
analyzed: sati saṃyoge tayoḥ prayojanam na asti sargasya  raṃga sthaḥ iti yathā raṃga sthaḥ iti evam upekṣakaḥ ekaḥ kevalaḥ śuddhaḥ puruṣaḥ tena aham
translated: Even when there is union between them, there is no purpose for creation.🔽Just as one on the stage, so one remains indifferent, thinking I have seen, the other ceases, thinking She has seen.

original: dṛṣṭeti kṛtvā uparatā nivṛtā ekā ekaiva prakṛtiḥ trailokyasyāpi pradhānakāraṇabhūtā🔽na dvitīyā prakṛtirasti mūrttibhede jātibhedādevaṃ prakṛtipuruṣayornirvṛttāvapi vyāpakatvāt
analyzed: dṛṣṭā iti kṛtvā uparatā nivṛtā ekā ekā eva prakṛtiḥ trailokyasya api pradhāna kāraṇa bhūtā  na dvitīyā prakṛtiḥ asti mūrtti bhede jāti bhedāt evam prakṛti puruṣayoḥ nirvṛttau api vyāpaka tvāt
translated: The one, the sole, pure Purusha, by that I have seen, thinking thus, one Nature alone has ceased, turned away, which is the primary cause of the three worlds.

original: saṃyogo 'sti na tu saṃyogāt kutaḥ sargo bhavati /
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ asti na tu saṃyogāt kutas sargaḥ bhavati
translated: There is no second Nature, for in the difference of forms there is the difference of species. Thus, even when Nature and Purusha have ceased, there is union due to their all-pervasiveness, but creation does not arise from union.

original: sati saṃyoge 'pi tayoḥ prakṛtipuruṣayoḥ sarvagatatvāt satyapi saṃyoge prayojanaṃ
analyzed: sati saṃyoge tayoḥ prakṛti puruṣayoḥ sarva gata tvāt sati api saṃyoge prayojanam
translated: Even when there is conjunction, since both Nature and the Spirit are all-pervading, even when there is conjunction, there is no purpose

analyzed: na asti sargasya sṛṣṭeḥ caritārtha tvāt prakṛteḥ dvividham prayojanam śabda viṣaya upalabdhiḥ guṇa puruṣa antara upalabdhiḥ ca
translated: of creation, because the creation has served its purpose. Nature has two purposes: the perception of objects of sound and the perception of the difference between the qualities and the Spirit.

original: ubhayatrāpi caritārthatvāt sargasya nāsti prayojanaṃ yaḥ punaḥ sarga iti /
analyzed: ubhayatra api caritārtha tvāt sargasya na asti prayojanam yaḥ punar sargaḥ iti
translated: Since the creation has served both purposes, there is no purpose of creation again.

original: yathā dānagrahaṇanimitta uttamarṇādhamarṇayordravyaviśuddhau satyapi saṃyoge na kaścidarthasambandho bhavati /
analyzed: yathā dāna grahaṇa nimitte uttamarṇa adhamarṇayoḥ dravya viśuddhau sati api saṃyoge na kaścid artha sambandhaḥ bhavati
translated: Just as when the creditor and debtor have paid off the debt due to the gift and acceptance, even though there is conjunction, there is no connection of any purpose.

analyzed: evam prakṛti puruṣayoḥ api na asti prayojanam iti
translated: Thus, there is no purpose for Nature and the Spirit either.

original: yadi puruṣasyotpanne jñāne mokṣo bhāti tato mama kasmānna bhavatīti / ata ucyate /
analyzed: yadi puruṣasya utpanne jñāne mokṣaḥ bhāti tatas mama kasmāt na bhavati iti atas ucyate
translated: If liberation results for the Spirit when knowledge arises, then why does it not happen for me? To this it is said:

analyzed: samyak jñāna adhigamāt dharma ādīnām akāraṇa prāptau
translated: When the causes of Dharma etc. are not obtained due to the attainment of perfect knowledge,

analyzed: tiṣṭhati saṃskāra vaśāt cakra bhrama vat dhṛta śarīraḥ
translated: The body remains sustained by the force of impressions, like the rotation of a wheel.

original: yadyapi pañcaviṃśatitattvajñānaṃ samyak jñānaṃ bhavati tathāpi saṃskāravaśāddhṛtaśarīro
analyzed: yadi api pañcaviṃśati tattva jñānam samyak jñānam bhavati tathā api saṃskāra vaśāt hṛta śarīraḥ
translated: Even though the knowledge of the twenty-five principles is perfect knowledge, the body remains sustained by the force of impressions,

original: yogī tiṣṭhati kathaṃ cakrabhramavaccakrabhrameṇa tulyaṃ yathā kulālaścakraṃ bhramayitvā
analyzed: yogī tiṣṭhati katham cakra bhrama vat cakra bhrameṇa tulyam yathā kulālaḥ cakram bhramayitvā
translated: How does the yogi remain like the rotation of a wheel? Just as a potter, having made the wheel spin,

original: ghaṭaṃ karoti mṛtpiṇḍaṃ cakramāropya punaḥ kṛtvā ghaṭaṃ paryāmuñcati cakraṃ bhramatyeva
analyzed: ghaṭam karoti mṛd piṇḍam cakram āropya punar kṛtvā ghaṭam paryāmuñcati cakram bhramati eva
translated: makes a pot, having placed a lump of clay on the wheel, and having made the pot, releases the wheel, the wheel continues to spin

analyzed: saṃskāra vaśāt evam samyak jñāna adhigamāt utpanna samyak jñānasya dharma ādīnām akāraṇa prāptau
translated: due to the force of the potter's stick. In the same way, for one who has attained perfect knowledge, after the arising of perfect knowledge, when dharma etc. become non-causes,

original: etāni sapta rūpāṇi bandhanabhūtāni samyagjñānena dagdhāni yathā nāgninā dagdhāni
analyzed: etāni sapta rūpāṇi bandhana bhūtāni samyak jñānena dagdhāni yathā na agninā dagdhāni
translated: these seven forms which are bondage, being burned by perfect knowledge, are not burned by fire

original: bījāni prarohaṇasamarthānyevametāni dharmādīni bandhanāni na samarthāni /
analyzed: bījāni prarohaṇa samarthāni evam etāni dharma ādīni bandhanāni na samarthāni
translated: like seeds that are not capable of sprouting. In the same way, these bonds of dharma etc. are not capable.

analyzed: dharma ādīnām akāraṇa prāptau saṃskāra vaśāt dhṛta śarīrāḥ tiṣṭhati jñānāt varttamāna dharma adharma kṣayaḥ
translated: When dharma etc. become non-causes, they remain with the body held by the force of the impressions. The destruction of present dharma and adharma occurs due to knowledge.

original: kasmānna bhavati varttamānatvādeva kṣaṇāntare kṣayamapyeti jñānaṃ tvanāgatakarma
analyzed: kasmāt na bhavati varttamāna tvāt eva kṣaṇa antare kṣayam api eti jñānam tu anāgata karma
translated: Why does it not occur? Due to being present itself, it also perishes in another moment. But knowledge of future karma

original: dahati varttamānaśarīreṇa ca yat karoti tadapīti vihitānuṣṭhānakaraṇāditi saṃskārakṣayāccharīrapāte mokṣaḥ // //
analyzed: dahati varttamāna śarīreṇa ca yat karoti tat api iti vihita anuṣṭhāna karaṇāt iti saṃskāra kṣayāt śarīrapāte mokṣaḥ
translated: And what he does with the present body also burns. Thus, liberation is attained upon the fall of the body due to the exhaustion of impressions, by performing what is enjoined.

analyzed: sa kiṃviśiṣṭaḥ bhavati iti ucyate
translated: What kind of special one does he become? This is being stated.

analyzed: prāpte śarīrabhede caritārtha tvāt pradhāna vinivṛttau
translated: When the change of body is attained, and the purpose is fulfilled, and the primordial nature ceases,

analyzed: aikāntikam ātyantikam ubhayam kaivalyam āpnoti
translated: he attains both absolute and ultimate liberation.

original: dharmādharmajanitasaṃskārakṣayāt prāpte śarīrabhede caritārthatvāt pradhānasya nivṛttau
analyzed: dharma adharma janita saṃskāra kṣayāt prāpte śarīrabhede caritārtha tvāt pradhānasya nivṛttau
translated: When the change of body is attained due to the exhaustion of impressions produced by virtue and vice, and the purpose of the primordial nature is fulfilled, and it ceases,

analyzed: aikāntikam avaśyam ātyantikam anantarhitam kaivalyam kevala bhāvāt mokṣaḥ ubhayam aikāntika ātyantikam iti eva
translated: he attains both absolute and ultimate liberation. Absolute means necessary, ultimate means uninterrupted, liberation is moksha due to the state of being alone.

analyzed: viśiṣṭa kaivalyam āpnoti
translated: He attains special liberation.

analyzed: puruṣa artha jñānam idam guhyam parama ṛṣiṇā samākhyātam
translated: This knowledge of the human goal has been declared by the supreme sage,

analyzed: sthiti utpatti pralayāḥ cintyante yatra bhūtānām
translated: where the creation, origin, and dissolution of beings are contemplated.

original: puruṣārtho mokṣastadarthaṃ jñānamidaṃ guhyaṃ rahasyaṃ paramarṣiṇā śrīkapilarṣiṇā
analyzed: puruṣa arthaḥ mokṣaḥ tad artham jñānam idam guhyam rahasyam parama ṛṣiṇā śrī kapila ṛṣiṇā
translated: This knowledge of the human goal, which is liberation, has been declared by the supreme sage, the illustrious Kapila, as a secret, a mystery.

original: samākhyātaṃ samyaguktaṃ yatra jñāne bhūtānāṃ vaikārikāṇāṃ sthityutpattipralayā avasthānāvirbhāvatirobhāvāścintyante
analyzed: samākhyātam samyak uktam yatra jñāne bhūtānām vaikārikāṇām sthiti utpatti pralayāḥ avasthāna āvirbhāva tirobhāvāḥ cintyante
translated: That which is well-known, well-said, where the states, origin, dissolution, existence, manifestation, and disappearance of the modifications of the elements are considered,

original: vicāryante yeṣāṃ vicārāt samyak pañcaviṃśatitattvavivecanātmikā sampadyate saṃvittiriti // //
analyzed: vicāryante yeṣām vicārāt samyak pañcaviṃśati tattva vivecana ātmikā sampadyate saṃvittiḥ iti
translated: are discussed, by the consideration of which, the knowledge consisting of the discrimination of the twenty-five principles is accomplished.

analyzed: sāṃkhyam kapila muninā proktam saṃsāra vimukti kāraṇam hi
translated: The Sāṃkhya was expounded by the sage Kapila, which is the cause of liberation from worldly existence.

analyzed: yatra etāḥ saptatiḥ āryāḥ bhāṣyam ca atra gauḍapāda kṛtam
translated: Herein are the seventy Āryas, and the commentary on it is composed by Gauḍapāda.

analyzed: uncommented kārikās
translated: Uncommented Kārikās.

analyzed: etat pavitryam agryam muniḥ āsuraye nukampayā pradadau
translated: This most sacred [teaching] the sage [Kapila] out of compassion bestowed upon Āsuri.

original: āsurirapi pañcaśikhāya tena ca bahulīkṛtaṃ tantram // //
analyzed: āsuriḥ api pañcaśikhāya tena ca bahulīkṛtam tantram
translated: Āsuri also bestowed it upon Pañcaśikha, and by him the system was greatly propagated.

analyzed: śiṣya paramparayā āgatam īśvarakṛṣṇena ca etat āryābhiḥ
translated: And this [teaching] which came down through a succession of disciples, was condensed by Īśvarakṛṣṇa into these Āryas.

analyzed: saṅkṣiptam ārya matinā samyak vijñāya siddhāntam
translated: Having thoroughly understood the conclusion, Āryamati [composed] this [commentary].

analyzed: saptatyām kila yaḥ rthāḥ te rthāḥ kṛtsnasya ṣaṣṭitantrasya
translated: The topics of the Saptati, it is said, are the topics of the entire Ṣaṣṭitantra.

analyzed: ākhyāyikā virahitāḥ paravāda vivarjitāḥ ca iti
translated: [But] devoid of stories and free from the arguments of others.
